The movie is a touching portrayal of the emotions tied to faith and religious devotion, beautifully blending innocence, joy, and human connection. From the very first scene, the film captures a deep sense of spirituality without being preachy. It shows how religion, at its core, brings happiness, peace, and a sense of belonging - not just for adults but for children as well.
Fantastic.

Unexpectedly hilarious. Spent the hour laughing hysterically at the mind boggling images and playing bingo with the excessively repeated phrases - deciding that it would quickly get you smashed if you turned it into a drinking game. Also, I need to know if the poor actress that played host needs help. She actively looked like she was holding back her own hysterics as she "read" the script.
I've read that someone wrote that you need to see this movie if you "love animals" ... really? They actually tranquilize a poor tiger just for the fun of it. That scene was really not needed.

Celebrating the life of a towering figure can be a challenge to get right, and that's precisely where this profile of poet, advocate and educator Nikki Giovanni comes up short. Writer-directors Joe Brewster and MichÃ¨le Stephenson earnestly but regrettably struggle to capture the nature and character of this African-American icon of literature and activism, whose 60+-year career has borne witness to the wide-ranging history of the nation's social and cultural movements during that time. Giovanni's take on these subjects has nearly always been radical and unreserved, with criticisms and commentary unapologetically leveled against the initiatives of both the right and the left when she felt the need to express them, frequently making her a lightning rod for attention from opponents on both ends of the spectrum. At the same time, though, she has always made her views known with an eloquently poetic touch, making it difficult for naysayers to find fault with her incisive, spot-on observations. By all rights, this is a life that would seem to provide the makings for an intriguing biography, but, unfortunately, that outcome doesn't materialize as effectively as it might have. The problem rests with the organization of the material included in the film, which at times seems quite scattered, particularly in the unfocused opening half. To its credit, this offering develops a greater sense of lucidity the further one gets into the narrative, but it's too bad that it doesn't live up to this potential throughout. Had it done so, this would have been one of the better documentaries of 2023, but, as it stands now, "Going to Mars" leaves audiences with a somewhat frayed portrayal of its subject, at least at the outset. Reading her works, in the end, may ultimately offer viewers a clearer and more complete picture of its principal, someone whose outspoken outlooks truly deserve to be better known at such a critical time in our nation's history.

Besides the cinematography, which is astonishing, with a beautiful balance between thrilling images of a real tiger and cinematic natural landscapes, the film tells a story about loss and betrayal in a light manner, making the audience laugh out loud in apparently tense moments. The film is a well-done tragi-comedy and I have never seen a Romanian film fit so well in the fine line between artsy festival films and commercial films, made with care and love for the audience. The main character is Vera, a female veterinarian who is strong and also soft, both tough and elegant and loves animals deeply. As a woman myself, I enjoy seeing a powerful female character on screen with all of her strengths and weaknesses, without the need of the writer-director to portray her unidimensionally tough. In the same way, the antagonist, her husband, played by Paul Ipate, is guilty of hurting her but at the same time you see his weak, human nature. The author understands relationships dynamics and the film doesn't judge its characters, but loves and tries to understand them. I wish it last longer and I hope the people will go to cinema and see it. The music is also beautiful and adds to the experience of seeing it.

An inspirational look at poet Nikki Giovanni who has lived a life and has a great ability to connect with her poetry over many years. It is fascinating to hear her being interviewed by James Baldwin. Beautiful voiceovers of Nikki reciting her poems with accompanying images. Poignant and yet very real and unapologetic in her thoughts and opinions :
"travels through time and space to reveal the enduring influence of Nikki Giovanni, one of America's greatest living artists and social commentators. Giovanni reckons with the inevitable passing of time in intimate vÃ©ritÃ© and revealing archival footage." Rotten Tomatoes.

I'm still thinking about Going to Mars: The Nikki Giovanni Project weeks after having seen it. The film itself is a poem about poetry, time, space and speaking truth. It effortlessly travels through different phases of Giovanni's life, creating a rich, full portrait that doesn't shy away from controversy. I now get why Giovanni says black women are the ideal explorers to send to Mars, in a way that I didn't understand by reading her words. Keep a look out for this film, hopefully coming to a theater near you! The visuals, music and readings all transport you to Giovanni's world. It's an exhilarating place to be.

Going to Mars: The Nikki Giovanni Project is breathtaking visual masterpiece, blending her poetry, vintage film, and current day footage to tell the life and journey of a master poet. On one level, it's visually captivating, impossible to look away. At its core, it's a powerful composition of Giovanni and poetry across the decades. Though some poetry and vignettes are 50+ years old, the words and power are undeniably timeless, speaking across generations, races, and spaces. I didn't want this documentary to end and it will undoubtedly spark new explorers, including myself, into Nikki Giovanni's writings.

Good idea, bad realization, cheap humor and jokes. Thing with western music motives is unnecessary, dialogs are very poor with lot of curse words. It looked very promising at the beginning, but throughout the movie I realized it is very disappointing.

It's a great movie, but one that doesn't have many well-known actors, which has likely contributed to it being underexposed in the media. The lack of big names may have led to it flying under the radar for many viewers. It can be a bit tricky to find a place to watch it, but if you manage to track it down, it's definitely worth the effort. The humor is spot on, with clever moments that will make you laugh, and the storyline is a perfect fit for the mentality of people in this part of Europe. It feels authentic and relatable. Overall, I would highly recommend giving this film a watch. It's an enjoyable and unique experience that deserves more recognition.

Its a Great Sinhala Comedy Movie with Amazing Dubbing and also Great Music , 3d Animations was very good for the First attempt , Must say the Dubbing Cast and the Direction is Top Notch, its not a Surprise that the best Artists in SL were Involve this .
Main characters acting skills are equal to zero. Me and my friends ( who aren't actors ) could create more realistic performance than the main actor of this movie.

Movie is enjoyable and recommend to watch with friends or family. The most fascinating thing was attention to detail of the surroundings. It was great to see Sri Lankan landscapes recreated in a 3D movie and production crew has done it greatly. There were many good 3D elements, but not the best 3D experience.

This is first 3D film on srilankan cinema history . Really didnt expected this movie. Graphics quality was awesome and story line was very funny . And characters are very smooth. Its become a era on sri lankan film industry.im hope next film was become more than good film.
GAJAMAN the first ever 3D animated movie in Sri Lanka directed by the most talented Chanaka Perera, starring the very best!
First of all CONGRATULATIONS & THANK YOU for the CAST & CREW behind the GAJAMAN 3D. You guys are just AMAZING!!!
This is the 1 st srilankan 3d animation movie Using Motion Capture Technology. This movie directed By Most Telented Chanaka Perera. I Love This Movie.

I watched this movie twice. This is gonna be a big s
step from sri lankan film industry. This movie is fantastic. I really enjoyed with it. Thanks to be gajaman movie crew member. This movie is gonna be a crazy..While watching this film, I could not imagine that this is a Sri Lankan film. This film proves that Sri Lanka has not taken a step but a giant step away from traditional film making.

Just beacause it's the first one doesn't mean it's the best. Over excited easily pleased toxic fanbase has put this boring mobie to top ratings. The effort should be appreciated but it's not early 90s anymore. World cinema,animation movies have evolved so much but they could have just come up with a better story. They have sold this garbage through a false hype. The jokes are almost decade old and laughter is overdue. IF they make another sequel for this they better come up with better story and charcter development. Overall movie is watchable(barely) but this hype is misleading cashgrab. Sri Lankan people should learn to recognize what's good and what's bad in cinema.

Yo, guys, let me tell you about this Sri Lankan 3D animated movie called Gajaman. Now, I'm not gonna lie, the first half of the movie was pretty decent. But then, oh boy, the final 10 minutes were a total mess.

This film is visually stunning. It simply has to be seen on the best on sri lankan cinema.biggest win of startin first 3d. That's the best way to enjoy this film just let it consume you. The story is one that most people can get behind and it's enhanced by the visual storytelling on screen. I haven't looked at the film in detail because so much happened and it was so visually engulfing. I'm not saying the story is perfect but the 1 hour+ runtime helped flesh out all of the characters and give the story depth and weight that you only really get with TV series theses days.thank to everyone in behind of this awesome work.

First of all this is the first Sri Lankan animation film so certainly this movie have some symbolic value
but unfortunately this movie don't contain and unique qualities or animation for 10/10 rating,
this is a made in SriLanka movie so it should contain some srilankan attributes . Yes the environment looks authentic.
Well, If this was the 1st ever movie I watched in my life, I'll give it a 10 star rating, but they could've done this far better than this.

This is a wonderful animation film that definitely surprised me! Expecting it to be another average animation film, I was delighted to find it was not quite so. First of all, the animation is extremely well done which makes the movie enjoyable to watch. The amount of details is astonishing and watching it twice was not a punishment for me. The plot is also surprisingly well thought-of, being funny yet dramatic and it keeps you on your seat while also making you laugh multiple times. It really does feel like everything took years to develop as the environment is complex and believable and the characters resemble their real-life counterparts remarkably well. It's amazing how they could produce a movie with simple jokes suitable for kids yet still silently addressing real-life issues at the same time. At last, I definitely recommend this movie for the whole family as I deem it enjoyable for all ages.
Top level 3d animation film with top level dubbing!! Hope you all enjoy and wish they earn enough so they can make the second part as people will love to see that!!!

Was blown away by the CGI work. The characters were realistic & the story was engaging. The soundtrack perfectly complemented the film. A highly recommended and memorable movie experience. I really enjoyed the movie. Really funny. Hats off to all who worked really hard to make this possible.

Gajaman (2023) deserves credit as Sri Lanka's first fully animated feature film, a bold and ambitious step for the local cinema industry. However, beyond this historic achievement, the movie doesn't offer much that is truly remarkable.

As a First Attempt its quite good but surprised to see some rate this 10/10. Being honest the movie is overrated, and expected something more from the dialogues, Jokes are silly, have seen better dubbing from them in cartoons, There are some stolen characters and characteristics, It shows where we are in the movie world when people rate 10/10 for this. You should appreciate work of your country its true, But overrating it self damages the reputation of the movie when some keep watching it with such high hopes of 10/10 and suddenly endup with a total disappointment, Overall Its Not Good But OK!

. This is first 3D film on Sri Lankan cinema history . Really didn't expected this movie. Graphics quality was awesome and story line was very funny . And characters are very smooth. Its become a era on sri lankan film industry.im hope next film was become more than good film. Good creation movie screen play and editing. Thanks to actress and movie team this movie should gave very good experience with our life together and very excellent. Specialty thank the director and cast of producer and all movie teams and it means all team members.this movie tell secret messages from us.well done keep up.

First of all this has to be the worst animation movie and one of the woworst movies ever I have seen. No story and few irrelevant ridiculous jokes here and there. It should have stayed as a comic cartoon series in a newspaper and certainly doesn't deserve to be made as a movie. I don't understand why Sri Lankans rate this "trash" so high. Just because it is the first Sri Lankan 3D movie, it doesn't mean this is great. This is a bloody nightmare nothing else. It shows the state of Sri Lankan cinema too. Just a few gags here and there and people are overjoyed about this pure trash. This is an insult to the brains of the people.

Unfortunately it's a such piece of trash I wouldn't recommend to watch it even to my harshest enemies. The plot is another boring nonsense that all of us have seen so many times already. Nothing original there. Another matter is acting. Sorry to say, but it remainded me of a badly rehearsed school play. No talent there whatsoever... I am sure Lithuania has a lots of talented actors, but you won't see them in this movie. Dialogues are another cliche that you can find in all those cheep movies with no name and you don't even remember after an hour of watching it. The only good thing in this so called thriller is make up. Really.

Dear Asta,
Funny when person, who said that can't remember movie after hour writting such long review and even have time for it:) it's typical.. :)
You can have your opinion but your review it's just another piece of nothing, your cliche sentences shows nothing just some anger and no grasp about experimental genre or even acting. Even actress was invited to awards nominees evening as a candidate. An awards where commercial movies never gets nominated. The plot may not original and there are a similar movies out there, but details is everything, that's why this movie is one of the best for some people and for anothers is one of the worst. This is the main destination of movie- to make some feelings which lasts. As you- you can't even reccomend it to your enemy. :))

A compelling visual storytelling and masteful directing style. Actors did a great job too. Very atmospheric move with a gripping music. Actually I didin't expect that director and scriptwriter can be so brave and broke the rules. Very close to japanese or korean style, very underrated movie, honestly. Also I loved a colors of the movie. Dreams of Jacob fulfilled in such coool ways. Good luck for talented filmmaker, waitting for next works.

100% Recommended. Music,Dubbing,Animation Perfect. A memorable movie watched after many years. Even though it is the first 3D animation film in Sri Lanka, the way the film has been presented to the audience in a very sophisticated and skillful way is excellent. The music of the film can be mentioned as one of the main interesting things. The way the characters have been used as well as the dubbing has been done in such a way that no flaw can be seen. It can be described as a film made with the contribution of a large number of people as well as with great effort. Another special thing is Mr. Sunil Perera coming to mind.

Wow what a movie, absolutely a great movie. I think I saw the trailer of this movie back 2012 or 2013 and I always wanted to watch this since then. This movies is the best Sinhala comedy movie made after 1970s without a doubt. This movie proved that there are hell a lot of movie fans in Sri Lanka for Sinhala movies, but bringing them to cinemas is totally depends on the ability of the movie makers to understand what fans want until now it's not been done properly. I think this is the start of a new era in the Srilankan cinema. Wasthi music spiced up this movie in a fantastic way. I absolutely enjoyed every minute of this movie.

Gajaman is the first ever Sri Lankan 3D animation movie made with motion-capture technology. The production team may have gone to great lengths to make it stand out, and it appears that they were successful. Nice dubbing by famous and experienced artists makes the movie much better.

title: Nha Ba Nu
roles: (as Ngoc Giau Nghe Si Uu Tu)

review_text: Right, well of course I had not heard about this 2023 Vietnamese drama titled "Nha Ba Nu" (aka "The House of No Man") prior to getting a chance to sit down and watch it. And given my love and fascination with the Asian cinema, of course I opted to watch it without knowing anything about it. And on that account, then writer Hoang Ngoc Huyen Tran and director Tran Thanh had every chance to impress and entertain me.

This movie is terrible. It follow the motif of same type genres of tran thanh' movies. To be honest, this movie shouldn't to be shown on the cinema. It should be on Youtube at all. Waste of time and money.
This is a movie with a great message
I cried 3 times while watching because I sympathize with the characters in the movie. A heartwarming movie about family, parent-child relationship, young love and many meaningful messages.

Not bad at all. I'd say yes there could be more space for improvement. However the messages from the movie is more than just to take tears from audience. If you take time to think about life of each character, it carries a lot of lessons. I love the movie in general.

This movie made I cry a lot. Dialogue of the film is very realistic, the characters are built to resemble real life. I think every character in Nha Ba Nu has a story that everyone has experienced in their life.

We have enough mind-twisted time travel stories with impossible technologies. We need something down to earth and sincere. Yes, family and relationship are a common topics in Vietnamese movies and years after years, directors have been exploited it. But this topic will never get old. The movie aint trying to create anything too big or dramatic angles to grab attentions. It goes back to the most basic and natural but real story.
Good movie!

Everyone has family issues of some sort, and it's especially true with Asian/Vietnamese kids. This movie was able to grasp certain aspects of trauma and the healing afterward wirh the help of good cinematography and sound design. The acting overall was better than most Vietnamese movies in recent years especially the girl and the mother. Some dialogues from the brother-in-law and the girl are still a bit forced but they are at least have good meaning and lessons to it. Some might find it too much.

Maro prapanchem, is a very different concept, with intresting screen play, and the performance's by all the actors are just great, C. G in the movie was too good, DOP work in this film was just great. Background score,in this film will make you more engaging, a very daring choice for the both director and producers to choose, to attend this kind of concepts, like never before in T F I, eagarly waiting for the sequel of this film, especially i want to say about the director naveen garu, by writing this kind of difficult subject, he succeed in taking this kind of difficult subject and making in very easiest way to understand by the audience, all the very best to entire team, must watch movie.
Saw this at the 2023 Sundance Film Festival

An intruiging documentary that premiered at Sundance that will be super interesting for those seeking popular science themes, especially from the human perspective. It is mainly about breaking down remote communication, while reavealing a department in NASA that is rarely talked about - psygologists for astronauts. The film dive into the efforts they make to mitigate long journeys in space, and most particulary the expedition to Mars. The film does not go into details on the entire range of issues and solutions presented in it, but it certainly gives an emotional and intimate picture of the basic need for human connection, so to a large extent it is relevant for all of us humans here on earth.

A really cool film for anyone who likes space. It goes through the challenges that astronauts share with their families while going for space missions that will become longer and longer as humanity will push forward. It also shows some really uniqe expiriments happening on Earth. I find it particularly relevant in our post covid world. What does it mean to stay connected to your loved ones? Will technology really solve these issues? It is not your standard science film, being much more emotional and personal. Makes you wonder about where are we going with all the new types of communication devices and how it will affect human connections.

The characters of the movie are still with me days after watching the movie (at the Festival del Cinema di Porretta) I can't stop to think about Sam and Amal and the journey they have made together. I hope the movie finds its way to the masses in Italy. Some things could have been done differently, but as a film student and aspiring director, I am very impressed with the portrayal of the characters. You can see that the filmmakers know their characters, they know them in and out. The girl, Amal (Jwan Alqatami) and the man, Sam (Ashraf Barhom) would most likely have been in the running for the big prizes if this was an American or British film. Watch this gem.

Saw this at the Noordelijk film festival 2023 in Leeuwarden (NL). I'm glad that movies about immigration become more and more different from what we got force-fed in 2017, when the so-called immigration crisis peaked, and when many filmmakers tried to piggyback on the issues showcased in the news. At the time, I swore to avoid all movies about this topic for good and for all. I broke my oath recently, when I saw one that I marked as different (Io Capitano/The Captain 2023, by Matteo Garrone). And again, I broke the same oath for the second time for the movie at hand. So, there is still hope for the future that immigration issues will get a better and nuanced coverage than in 2017.

The refugee crisis (especially those escaping from Syria) is an issue that is finally getting its due cinematically, first with the Netflix fact-based offering "The Swimmers" (2022) and now with this impressive debut feature from writer-director Abbe Hassan. The film follows the odyssey of a young Syrian girl (Jwan Alqatami), travelling alone, who flees to Turkey from her homeland on her way to Sweden for a reunion with her sisters and parents. But, upon exiting the crowded shipping container that transported her on the first leg of her journey, she's met with a raid by Turkish immigration authorities, barely escaping in the unexpected company of one of the exploitive smugglers who organized her flight to freedom (Ashrof Barhom). Thus begins a trek through Europe as this seemingly mismatched duo makes its way to Sweden, a perilous trip that embroils the protagonists in an engaging array of challenges and revelations, especially the uncovering of the many different sides of these complex characters. As this story plays out, the filmmaker effectively weaves together elements from a variety of genres, including action-adventure tales, thrillers, emotionally touching dramas and road trip/buddy movies, successfully depicting the refugee saga for it truly is - a bittersweet experience filled with joys, triumphs, disappointments and tragedies. It draws much-needed attention to the plight of these downtrodden souls seeking safety from an insane conflict that's needlessly displacing so many innocents caught in the crossfire, just one of many such clashes currently occurring around the world. "Exodus" is a genuinely compelling watch, one that truly deserves a mainstream theatrical distribution, as well as recognition for the attention it so absorbingly draws to this urgently heartbreaking crisis.

I created this account to write this, my first review ever, because "Exodus" is a film that truly moved me. As a teacher, I show it to my 6th and 7th graders, and every time, it sparks some of the most beautiful and important discussions in my classroom. The movie isn't just about the refugee crisis-it's about friendship, survival, and finding hope even in the worst situations.

Such a beautiful and important movie with great actors. The girl is magnetic. The guy you recognize from several other films. The movie feels very authentic. A road movie where I got a sense of what it is like to be on the run. I like that you were close to and with the main characters throughout the movie. Maybe there was a bit too much music for my taste but it is very nice. The movie is a perfect mix of American cinema and a European one.

The film tells the story of a girl, Amal (Jwan Alqatami), who escapes a Turkish police raid on a container carrying refugees and joins up with smuggler Sam (Ashraf Barhom). They then sail across the Mediterranean to Greece and Romania, where the plot becomes somewhat complicated.

Oh man, a little time capsule of greatness. Watch this! The birth of Young Adult fiction, the importance of writing the way things are rather than the way someone tells you they should be - kids loved her so much. A truth teller. So relevant to today also! Now I need to go on a Judy Blume binge!
"I sell banned books" is the sign in her Florida bookstore today.

As "Judy Blume Forever" )2023 release; 98 min) opens, today's Judy Blume is reading an excerpt from her 1973 children's book "Deenie", and we see Judy, now 85, running her "Books & Bools" store in Key West. We then go back in time to Judy's upbringing and youth as a Jewish girl, and her keen interest in imagining fictional characters. At this point we are less than 10 minutes into the movie.
I loved getting to know the woman who wrote all those incredible books. She literally helped me through puberty and all of high school.

I came upon this documentary purely by accident, and I'm so glad I did. Judy Blume and her books are inextricably linked to my childhood and for that I'm so grateful. The first book I read on my own, for pleasure, was Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing, in 1978 at 7 years old. For the next couple years I discovered and devoured the rest of her catalog at that time. It didn't matter to me that most of her books centered on girls. I also became a voracious reader because of Judy, and sought out similar books only a few authors were writing, like Norma Klein and Paula Danziger.

Greetings again from the darkness. It's not unusual for readers to feel a connection to their favorite author, but very few can match the bond shared by writer Judy Blume and her followers. Co-directors Davino Pardo and Leah Wolchok set out to profile the writer whose staggering sales figures (more than 80 million books sold) pale in comparison to the impact she had on so many young girls.

As someone who grew up with Judy Blume books, this documentary was very important and very powerful. To hear Judy Blume speak so poignantly about her own life in terms of the messages she wanted to share was amazing.

I have to say what a breath of fresh air. You covered so many things from my childhood and my life that you had me one minute crying like a baby then laughing out loud I woke my wife who had fallen asleep next to me a few times. I find myself a parent again in later years and was wondering how to breach all the seen taboo subjects that as a child I had no help in dealing with. I will be investing some time into your books to hopefully not leave my little person blindly fumbling in life at difficult times. I have to say how brave all your guests were on the film to share their experiences and to do it themselves without a mask or fake name. I apologize for the review if it does not read correctly as I am dyslexic and find it hard sometimes to write. Also, my spelling is not the best but Google spelling helps a little. Thank you Judy for being uncensored and you. If you are reading this and think shall I give this a look then the answer is YES 100% ATB Kind regards Derek.

Judy's books were no doubt timely, but I wouldn't go so far as to glorify them as a noble cause. She would have been better off helping parents understand how to communicate better with their own children. Your kids belong to you. Judy wants to parent them for you through her books. She saw a hole in the market where parents were falling short in communication and so she provided information and emotional support for them through her books. Her books are about exploring your feelings, bodies, sexuality but lack depth and knowledge on much more important philosophical issues. For instance, how can one make a decision about which religion to choose when given zero information about either one (Are You There God, It's Me, Margaret?). It pained me to watch this over glorification of teen girls exploring their feelings. It did however enlighten me as to why so many people are struggling to thrive these days...it is a lack of parenting. If you don't teach your kids a worldview...how to reason, think and work, they will inevitably fall into just following their desires and feelings. If you don't have difficult conversations on a regular basis, other people will teach things to your kids. Don't let Judy (or any other author) parent for you.

Thoroughly watchable documentary of a beloved author. Never met Judy before but I connected to her through her books. Tiger Eyes being my favorite. The documentary was interesting especially when focused on the backlash her books faced in the Regan era. Also interesting to see was the amount of fan mail she received and that she kept the letters! As usual the "gatekeepers" at Prime same as at Netflix, Hulu, etc made sure to insert their plight into the documentary about a 83 year old woman who writes books. A huge turn off for me, but thankfully I was able to fast forward through certain sections. A must watch if you are a Judy Blume fan.

As a teen, I read books like "Are You There God, It's Me, Margaret" and "Then Again, Maybe I Won't" and marveled at how matter-of-fact certain subjects not previously discussed in other fictional books I read were explored. I later read the more mature book "Forever..." and thought how author Judy Blume had grown as a writer. I also read another book about her that told how many of those of her novels were banned because of those certain subjects. So I was very interested in this documentary when I discovered it on a recent flight. As her fame grew, Ms. Blume gets interviewed by many of the famous talk show hosts of the time and also appeared in "Crossfire" where she debated with conservative figure Pat Buchanan who she didn't even know about previously. But the most touching parts is when she reads letters from many teen girls including a couple of those young women who wrote to her for years to the point that they both agreed to appear in this film talking of how much of an influence she had on them. Had she not decided to write for a living, Ms. Blume would be just another of those housewives just raising her kids and tending to her hubby when he gets home from work but that wasn't what she was comfortable with, that's for sure! She'd eventually leave her first spouse and after failing with her second, she'd eventually find true happiness with a third one who had a daughter who knew of his new wife's work. Ms. Blume herself had two offspring who eventually grew proud of her work. At 83, she seems happy now living in Key West, FL, running a book store where she proudly has on display inside the sign "We sell banned books" which I'm guessing includes her own! As a astute observer of adolescent life, Judy Blume Forever is aptly named.
The movie starts out by claiming that it is based on a true story...
I don't know why this movie has an average to higher rating. Oh, wait, I do, fake reviews. Don't be suckered by any saying anything positive about this badly put-together snore-fest.

How a "horror" movie can have such a short runtime but be so complete void of anything interesting is somewhat remarkable. Unfortunately Im on a losing streak tonight and this is the third barely watchable stinker in a row. Avoid. The only thing that could have made this one worse is the shaky cam nonsense, but that's not enough to give such a vapid experience any points. At about the 54 minute mark, there is a treacherous scene where 2 people accidentally stab each other to death. The absurdity of the scene in question in all its amazing glory caused me to go ahead and award +1 star, but think of it more as a razzie.

Heading to a remote island, a group of strangers looking to uncover the truth about the area's haunted past find that the stories about it being littered with broken dolls are true when they spot the mysterious objects there which gives them the chance to encounter the spectral owner of the dolls.

title: Nam June Paik: Moon Is the Oldest TV

review_text: Nobody in the movie can act. Nobody. The constant, constant shoehorning in of modern music as a score is distracting (maybe that's a good thing?) Rips off a lot of pseudoscientific jargon from other productions to "explain" things. Has the nerve to use the phrase "back to the future". The vacuum tubes in the radio with the cover off (and no other modification) that they used as part of the time machine wouldn't exist until 40 years after the period. Is he supposed to have traveled into the future to get the parts to invent the time machine? Any steampunk fan could have devised a better looking "invention". One extra star for actually having miked the people well, unlike most of these amateur productions where you can't hear people half the time.
I can only assume all the resoundingly positive reviews are by friends and family of the filmmakers.

This is a reasonable documentary, nothing revolutionary. It doesn't contain anything fans don't know. The editing isn't great, frequently they leave the narrators mistakes and/ or restarts in which is annoying and should have been picked up.

I checked this movie out from the library because it looked like a cute little rom-com (even if not super high quality). Unfortunately I had to stop watching about 15 minutes in. The acting seemed forced and the dialogue sounded forced and unnatural. Even the microphones were low-quality and muffled some of the actors' lines.

This movie was amazing and such a joy to watch. Great direction and eye-popping cinematography it was shot in New York's trendy West Village ! Full of laughs and very interesting. The story draws you in and you want to know what happens next it keeps you wanting more and more and i wasn't disappointed I stayed interested till the end. Great ending. You will love it. Funny Funny Funny. I look forward to seeing a sequel or a tv show about this. The characters are so fabulous written and they are so hilarious Townhouse Confidential is the perfect rom com to watch this Valentine's Day!!! Great love story !!!
Townhouse Confidential offers a modern, theatrical reimagining of Pride and Prejudice that's worth the watch.

A hilarious romp through the economics of love and real estate in New York's trendy West Village neighborhood! Samantha Simone is comic perfection as Liz Perry, the cash-strapped townhouse owner with a weakness for cupcakes and hot guys in skinny jeans, and Lee Tyler (George Barrow) is positively Darcy-esque as the arrogant real estate developer who tries to win her heart and buy her house. The two pint-size mafia guys (Joseph D'Onofrio and Al Linea) who lend George money to finance his hedgefunder Disneyland development project are completely over the top, and Jonas Barranca (Tommy Leroy) plays bad boy handyman Tommy Leroy with a laugh so comically maniacal that you want to love him despite his wicked ways. With a clever script, well-paced direction and eye-popping cinematography, Townhouse Confidential is the perfect rom com to watch this Valentine's Day!
Was this the most groundbreaking piece of film created? No, But did it take itself too seriously? Also no.

Townhouse Confidential is simply wonderful! Very fun and festive, quick moving and witty. Set in New York City, it's a modern take on a classic novel. The characters are great! I found myself rooting for them to have it all - and eventually ... well, no spoilers here.

Townhouse Confidential is a fun, well written and entertaining movie!! It is an absolute delight plus the "easter eggs" with nods to other classic movies make this enjoyable movie that much more enjoyable. The dialogue, the acting, the on location sets in the West Village of NYC contribute to a very fun experience. The characters are well developed, with the actors and actresses really leaning into their roles. The twists and turns along the way make sure to keep the audience guessing as to what will happen next and how will it all turn out. It's a great rom com to enjoy all year round and especially on Valentine's Day! Once you watch Townhouse Confidential you will want to watch it again and again.
This movie took the framework of Jane Austen's classic tale Pride and Prejudice and translated it into the modern warfare that is NYC's dating and real estate game.

Like one of the other reviews said, this documentary is very likely AI generated (not including the speakers), you can hear accidental repeats (one moment it said "In 1991, in 1991 Eminem was...") and repetitive wording ("beloved uncle Ronnie" was said several times). Throughout the documentary, his music is barely played with only about 2 to 3 exceptions. Overall, this documentary provides no real insight to Eminem aside from what we already know. At the end of the day this documentary feels like an hour plus long version of a Wikipedia article. Simply listening to the narrator, you can hear how it is a script being read by an AI.

This documentary is a letdown on several levels. The background music is constantly playing, and it's weird and doesn't fit with the content, creating a distracting atmosphere. The editing is sloppy, with noticeable mistakes by the narrator left in, and there are awkward silences that break the flow. It repeats itself a lot, making the same points over and over, which becomes tedious.
Really cheaply made, reuse of images over and over, weird blurry images and stock pictures of old America (no idea why). Almost every video clip is out of sync with the audio, any music video is out.

This film is seductive like all American Masters profiles. Their films are interesting and initially satisfying, but they leave an aftertaste of being suspiciously mild-very selective in what information they include (nothing troubling or disappointing about the subject) and thus emotionally manipulative. I wish they would allow more grit-to edit Fluxus artists as if they were a cuddly, harmonious crew is just weird. Ignoring Paik's wife Kubota was also bizarro. Nonetheless, Nam June Paik is such a fantastic subject that it's well worth watching this one just to see all the footage. They included a lot of video of him speaking, and he had an incredible way of speaking big thoughts succinctly and often humorously. A too shallow movie about an artist of real depth.
Saw this at the 2023 Sundance Film Festival.
I recognise the name, but that's about it and I do like a good documentary, so I'm looking forward to this - although I'm expecting to be thoroughly confused by it all.

I don't need Steve Yuen's dulcet tones to elucidate the genius that was Nam June Paik. I don't really see how the latter had an impact on the former. This is just a tool to make a somewhat mercurial subject more digestible for the masses, which is quite reductive honestly speaking. There was barely any exposition to really get at the heart of what made NJP so great. This is the kind of introductory course that spends 2hrs didactically telling us about his brilliance but skirts the chance to deeply explore the origins of that brilliance, and I suppose that is the strength of relying purely on archives. Moreover, the documentary telegraphs everything by following the conventions of chronological narration. Beginning with his early life in war-torn Korea, to his restless irreverent youth, to his maximal, big-scale mid-life period, to his very sad decline. I understand that for an audience who knows nothing about NJP, chronology is an easy form of exposition, however, this barely scratches the surface of his radicalism and complete rejection of art world greed. Unfortunately, decades after his death, his art has been desecrated into some form of commodity, which is the last thing he would have wanted. This is of no fault of the filmmaker, but rather the disgusting nature of art world auction houses and foundations.

Although intriguing at first "A House in Jerusalem" sadly falls flat in its second half. This picture surpasses the "ghost-story" genre with its eery gentle approach by leaving the horror and fright out of this picture, but unfortunately it also left out suspense and thrill that would captivate viewer's attention. I appreciated the truthful and realistic political background that was woven into almost every part of the main story. However the themes like loss and grief, that should have been in the foreground according to the director Muayad Alayan, were not as prominent or conspicuous as was promised. Yes, when you look back at "A House in Jerusalem", it is obvious that coping with sorrow and misfortune is the primary message of the picture. But on the other hand while watching it you get lost in the narrative a little bit and it almost feels more as a detective story. Overall it was not an unpleasant film, but at the same time watching it didn't evoke any emotions in me and because of that it became quite forgettable.

This is a movie that I got the chance to see via a screener thanks to Justin Cook. I'll admit, I originally wasn't going to check this out as I didn't think what I saw from the press release was horror. It wasn't until digging a bit that I saw that on Letterboxd, this falls in genre. I decided to go ahead and give it a watch after that. Aside from that, I did come into this one blind. Just having read the synopsis.

I did watch it in the festival and was surprised that it did pick up for the screens there. Don't want to be too harsh but will leave my negative opinion on that. It was hard to watch to the end, I didn't see anything good or worth attention at all.
9 out of ten - brilliant
I I'm not gonna explain why is it a pretty good movie, but this movie made me cry and grateful for my life, in the first half I thought it's a scary movie but it turned out that it's s not !!

Where to begin? The acting is absolutely wooden - these actors know how to read, not act. I've never seen any movie distributed like this. Cinematography? What cinematography!? This movie appears to have been shot on an iPhone and then edited using the most basic of movie suites. I mean kudos to the company, whoever they are, trying to make new Westerns but this is absolutely atrocious. The sound quality is dirt poor - you either can't hear the actors talking or they're blowing out your TV Speakers.

Reflect is a film with a completely new approach to screenwriting and directing. It's hard to compare it to anything else on the market because it's so fresh. For viewers looking to step into an entirely new way of filmmaking, this is the perfect film. Exploring metaphysical concepts of our world and beyond, it leaves you thinking about the possibilities of the universe while gently guiding you through a thrilling adventure. The mix of genres holds you in its grasp until the very end leaving you on your toes at every turning point. The colors in the film are stunning with the beautiful backdrop of Sedona as it's canvas. It's a very visually pleasing experience that soothes your mind to contrast the thrill of the chase that drives a certain high energy urgency in the name becoming new. Which all seems very fitting when taking into consideration the high risks that were taken in trying something new with the film altogether. I recommend this film to those who are tired of the same old and desire to challenge their minds with the possibility of a new normal. Can't wait to see more from this director.

This was such an amazing watch. If you like to explore spiritually or even just mentally you will be thrown for a ride of epic proportions. Everything here is top notch - especially the photography and ideas presented. It is not called "Reflect" just because, as it inspires reflection of ourselves and therefore will be super healing to the right person. It is dark yet light, funny yet serious, a paradox in the best sense of the word. Twists and spins all throughout, it will enliven your eyes. Dana Kippel is most certainly someone to follow and watch for in the coming years. Her dedication to this project is immensely inspiring to say the least. Definitely a must-watchðŸ’¯
Reflect is truly an experience. Gorgeous cinematography and creative story with solid writing.

This film is jam packed with ideas! The structure resembles more of a meditation or metaphysical trip than a traditional story arc. There are definitely some spirituality gems sprinkled throughout with some really fun and engaging moments. There are visuals and sequences that are mind bending and extremely impressive for the scale of the production. The ensemble does a great job nodding to the meta aspect of the film, having fun and not taking the material too seriously. Reflect explores themes that are right up my alley, so I'm really excited to see what Dana Kippel does with her second outing.

Loved the cinematography, symbolism, psychedelic journey, acting, exploration of mental health and trauma, film direction. It was unique and interesting - something that I've never seen before. Glad that I bought and watched this movie.

Is this really people getting paid to do this. These are reenactments.people roll playing and they spend their own money on uniforms and props. This is painful.do these people think they have a hit with this one. I hope no one wasted more than 3 mins of their time on this one. I would rather have watch water boil.pleasr in all seriousness why are they doing this,? Granted, when I stumbled upon this 2023 movie titled "Storm Over Georgia", I wasn't exactly harboring the biggest of expectations, as the movie's cover just wasn't all that interesting and sort of permeated of amateur hour. But since it was a movie that I had neither heard about or watched, of course I opted to check out and see what writer and director Christopher Forbes brought to the table...

Enjoyed the historical characters in the movie and the subject matter not covered by any other film. Watched the movie several times and enjoyed the viewing. Manipulative woman and a roguish men conduct a turbulent story during the Civil War. Confederate infantry, cavalry and artillery make a bold stand against the overwhelming numbers of the Union army during Sherman's March through eastern Georgia. The Union force then came up against a defensive line of barricades which they eventually overran. As the Union advance continued, they met more barricades which required time to overcome. Finally, the Confederates fell back to a final line of barricades within the town. After furious fighting, the Union troops broke through and Wheeler's force ran.

The film does a great job of showing both Heath Ledger's career successes and the sad parts of his personal life. It gives a full picture of a talented and successful man who faced serious struggles with depression, severe insomnia, and a drug addiction that eventually caused his early death. This documentary doesn't exaggerate his struggles but honestly reflects the pressures of being a star and the tragic outcomes that can result.
Ending of the film is so stupid and illogical like the film. The kanjoos family don't have 5000 rupees to install english toilet for grand mother with knees problems but donate lakhs to hospital.

Kanjoos majnu kharchili Laila is a movie that resonates well with the masses. Since all of us have dealt with some or the other Kanjoos in our life. But not all is about Kanjoosi in this film, the real richness of this film comes during the climax scenes where the audiences will be spell bound with the strong social message which this film has to give. Rajiv Thakur as kanjoos majnu is amazing. He is a total fit for the role. Shehnaz sehar as kharchili Laila is very promising and portrays her role with a lot of ease. The supporting actors including nirmal Rishi, Seema sharma Brijender Kala also provide strong substance to an already great storyline. It's a total paisa wasool must watch family entertainer.

Kanjoos Majnu Kharchilli Laila is a Punjabi movie released on 13 Jan, 2023. The movie is directed by Avtar Singh and featured Rajiv Thakur, Sehar Shehnaz, Nirmal Rishi and Brijendra Kala as lead characters. Starting of 2023, Punjabi industry gives a blockbuster comedy , i really love the story its new in the industry , both the actors plays there characters so well , especially shehnaz sehar, new in the industry did her character so beautiful , i think she has a bright future , and also Rajiv Thakur 's first project also played his character very well, overall its very beautiful movie with full of comedy and entertainment, and the climax of movie is too good. Now Streaming on Amazon Prime Video. ... I saw the Hindi Version.

Get ready to laugh your hearts out with 'Kanjoos Majnu Kharchili Laila', a rib-tickling Punjabi comedy that will leave you in stitches! This film is a masterclass in slapstick humor, witty one-liners, and impeccable comic timing.

"Kanjoos Majnu Kharcheelz Lailal" is more than just a comedy; it's a heartwarming exploration of what it means to live fully and love generously. With its relatable characters, sharp humor, and meaningful themes, the film appeals to a broad audience, inviting them to reflect on their own values and relationships. Whether you're looking for a good laugh or a deeper message, this film delivers on all fronts. "Kanjoos Majnu Kharcheelz Lailal" is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates clever storytelling that entertains while prompting introspection. It reminds us that while saving is important, it is the experiences we share and the love we give that truly enrich our lives. A cinematic gem that deserves recognition and a place in the hearts of viewers!

Kanjoos Majnu Kharchili Laila" is an outrageously entertaining comedy film that will keep you giggling from start to finish. This side-splitting movie is a masterclass in comedic storytelling, with each scene expertly crafted to leave audiences in stitches.

Its a kind of movie where you will laugh out your lungs at most places. This film is all about a young miser boy who fells in love with an extravagant beautiful girl. To enjoy every moment of life the female protagonist does her utmost to let the miser boy spend etravagantly and more often in the film he tries to escape from untouching his pocket but all in vain, which adds a flavour of dramatic comedy in the scenes.
An anti-hero type character, Spencer reminds me of Michael Douglas in Falling Down, but played with a quirky comedic performance that makes the film noir atmosphere very enjoyable.

The script is particularly bad. It takes a common genre of horror and violence against women and the misogynistic pitfalls and cliches that plague similar works. It somehow keeps you bored throughout-like when one seemingly disturbing act turns out to "just" be homicide, the clearly psychopathic mummy issues underlying the character's misogyny, the worst popcorn ever, and of course the unexpected ending that shows the different depths of depravity within all of us. The context of an acting casting call both creates a over the top theatrics while being brutally honest about the very real nightmares within the industry. Overall, the script is witty, provocative, cogent, and all too relevant.
If you like suspense and slow burn thrillers.
I have seen this twice now. Dark horror comedy at its best. Well shot great actors and great script.

First time I saw this film was on dvd, second time seen at The Lavenham Film Festival, Suffolk, where it won three awards at the Gala Awards night, which was very well deserved. Enjoyable film from the start to the end, with plenty of laughs throughout. Great casting, all characters were convincing and natural
Would happily watch again
Great cast,, each character drew you in.

An expertly written and tightly woven thriller. An amazing music score drives this film through a series of tense and chilling encounters. There is a traditional feel to this movie where the emphasis in on the story telling rather than cgi distractions. No half hearted mumbling here ....the performances are delivered with conviction and clarity. In classic hitchcock style there are some truly memorable jaw dropping moments of horror. There are some twists and turns at the end which will satisfy fans of the psychological thriller genre. Let's hope this is the big one for Raya films as they go from strength to strength.

This is such a good film. James and Caroline made such a superb suspenseful thriller that takes place in the British film industry and takes Harvey Weinstein's audition process to a whole new level. The acting was really good and well conveyed throughout the entire thing. Probably the only let down was perhaps the soundtrack. Might have been a little over the top at times. The camerawork is really good and got Hitchcock vibes to it. Take the time and watch this original horror flick and I mean horror lightly as there's no jump scares or actual horrific moments. Minor gore and blood to don't worry!

I knew to expect horror; I did not expect such wit and humour as well! The unexpected one-liners and situational comedy were such a delight amidst all the creepiness. This was just an excellent black comedy, and every piece came together to fuel its success: from the near cinematography to the haunting score.

How many actors would gather at a slightly dingy casting suite for a shot at a role in a Hollywood movie? Plenty, it would seem - and without doing the necessary checks to see whether the opportunity is quite what is advertised.
I loved this film. With all the references to the classic horror genre subtly put in place, it's a wonderful feel good movie on a small budget.

A well scripted, performed, filmed & scored horror film that reflects the movie industry tropes with aplomb and dark humor. The journey of auditioning actors and their archnemesis in the guise of a casting director, moves you through the day in the life with the added twist of horror (no spoilers!). The story is told with an ode to Hitchcock flare and a fun, popcorn worthy viewers experience. The musical score perfectly reflects the genre, though at times, seems to overshadow the scenes - but we get it! You think you know which characters you're rooting for, but you don't. So, enjoy the plot twists and the shocking, delightful journey, where you come to feel for everyone in it - in this industry.
Casting Kill is an intense thriller, it's highly entertaining and equally disturbing horror with a splash of Hollywood glamour, a pinch of American Psycho and a touch of Hitchcock.

Casting Kill. Which was shot super- quickly, with a small crew, and on a very limited budget, is a very stylish suspense thriller set in the underbelly of Hollywood filmmaking Nothing is ever quite as it seems and, indeed, Casting Kill has more twists and turns than a corkscrew. The whirlwind indie writer/ director team of Carline Spence and James Smith have been building a well=deserved reputation of late, and they are sure to have another micro - budget hit on their hands with CASTING KILL, a tense and stylish horror/ thriller hybrid with plenty of short, sharp shocks. Like a kick in the eye from a stiletto heel.

Unexpected twists in this very enjoyable and well executed film by Raya Films. At the start of the film you really have no idea where it will eventually lead. An actors worst nightmare led by Rob Laird in a chillingly cool, skin crawling manner. Great cast ( really enjoyed Jack Forsyth Noble as Dominic as he manages to get under the skin of this supposed Hollywood Director). A terrific score by Shaun Finnegan which enhances the mood dramatically. It's a well written script by Caroline Spence, interspersing humour whilst maintaining an air of suspense with atmospheric cinematography by James Smith.

Sometimes no need to add any comments, just enough to write 'excellent' and for required 600 characters, I can write that 60000 times... Perfect narration, perfect documentary, perfect personality. I feel so grateful for having a star like Yildiz Kenter in the name of my country. In my opinion this country has to give her name to all art schools or some streets.. She is a real star like her name.. I watched this documentary with lots of feeling, sometimes sad generally happy. I think this is another level for theater, I mean working too much like her, it is unbelievable. Almost her whole life passed with theater. Perfect production. I love it from beginning to the end. Rip Yildiz Kenter. We will never forget you.
