I have always been a BIG supporter of Steven Greer, but I have recently heard him say things that are patently UNTRUE, and are outright lies. The aliens are NOT your friends! I am also not waiting ANOTHER 22 years for ~NOTHING~ to happen. Only the most naive among us still hold out hope that the next 2 decades are going to be any different in terms of results. Not to mention the vast amounts of disinformation about the aliens themselves Greer is spouting, which is truly astounding! They are NOT your "friends". They are NOT here to help anyone. They don't want to educate you, or heal you OR help you be a better human being! They only protect this planet and it's lifeforms because THEY are the ones who 'seeded' everything on it from weeds to whales. This planet is NOT an "experiment", it is a 'FARM' essentially where anything and anyone can be taken and used whenever and however it, or they are needed, or it suits them. The landlords have changed over the last few billion years, but the purpose is basically the same. The earth 'houses' very diverse and valuable life forms! Mainly because it's a water-planet.
During the opening credits, I thought this was going to be a good short movie.

Those of you that enjoy a fast paced, thriller with plot, twists, and jump, scares will find it a worthwhile watch! I was hooked from the start as the characters seem real and the plot is believable, with an ending that will leave you in disbelief! I will recommend this movie to all my friends and family!

Seclusion (2023), directed by Lovinder Gill, completely surprised me in the best possible way. This is one of those rare indie thrillers that pulls you in with its atmosphere, its quiet tension, and a lead performance that feels both vulnerable and powerful.

"Seclusion" grabs your attention and runs away with it from its opening scene right through its final shot. Many films feel as if they dare you to guess where their story is taking you, only to drop you in the middle of nowhere for little more than shock value. Not only does "Seclusion" avoid this lazy trope, it masterfully keeps you in the dark for exactly as long as you need in order to leave with a smile on your face and a ton of "what's next?" Questions on your mind!
Saw this at the 2023 Sundance Film Festival.

Ella Gledining presents us here with an emotionally charged documentary that follows her search for people with a similar disability to herself. She has a rare bone disorder which essentially means that she has bones missing from her legs. Aside from some fairly tortuous surgery when she would have been young, followed by some prosthetics, she was destined to remain smaller but otherwise just as intellectually capable, vibrant and ambitious as anyone else. We follow her determination to have a family (with the sparingly featured Scott) and then her own quest to use the internet to find others with whom she can share experiences, chat and perhaps bond. Glendining is an engaging lady who seems very much from the glass half full school of philosophy. Even when clearly exhausted - mentally and physically, she retains an optimism that together with their young son River seems to help sustain her when the black clouds loom. As ever, though, with one person filmmaking, it's not always the most objective of analysis about much of the rest of the population whom she routinely defines as "ableist". Her assertions that society suffers from this flaw is fairly flawed in itself. What is society? It isn't just some sort of concrete jigsaw puzzle into which her tiny piece uncomfortably fits. It's a myriad of different people, personalities, abilities, attitudes - and not many, I suspect, are actually as hostile or indifferent to those less able as she seems to think. "The world is better with the disabled in it"? Well who would argue? What is a disability anyway? Broader society is riddled with racism, homophobia, intolerances and we all live in a sort of Venn diagram model style of overlapping circles with each allowing for the differing aspects of human nature regardless as to how or if people may choose to compartmentalise themselves. Clearly this lady hasn't had a straightforward time, but she can come across as just a little inclined to paint everyone else with the same brush. A "normal" life is an entirely subjective term and what's great to see here is that she seems focussed on ensuring that her family have exactly that - work notwithstanding - and she presents us with an interesting look at just how she intends to live life to the full. Not perfect, but worth ninety minutes.

Is There Anybody Out There? From Brighton-based director Ella Glendining is a self-professed love letter to the disabled community and anyone who has ever felt other. It is a formidable debut feature by a filmmaker who has refused to allow society's expectations or prejudices about her disability to stand in her way, instead using her tenacity to build a career in a notoriously difficult and ableist industry.

Could emphasise so much in respect of how able bodied people view us disabled people. I cannot state that my disability is the same, again we are all unique and there is no norm. I had polio when I was three years of age, I do remember some fleeting moments of that time believe it or not. I was totally struck down to begin with, but within a period of time only my left leg was affected...making it shorter and little to no muscle. Eventually I wore steel calipars on my affected leg. Surgery intervention to fix foot and ankle.

The Miracle Baby is a bold attempt at a remake of the classic 1982 Indonesian horror film. Amidst the rising trend of horror remakes in Indonesia, this film stands out for its technical ambition and stellar ensemble cast.

Premiered at Sundance, Jamojaya portrays an upcoming Indonesian rapper and his father/former manager, wrestling with grief, independence, whether to let go or hold on, and staying true to one's self. While there's a certain predictability with the music career storyline, the movie shines for the unique depth and pain brought to the screen in the father-son relationship. This film can be somewhat slow, particularly when the focus is on the music story over the father-son story. Indonesian star Yayu Unru delivers a breathtaking performance as the father, cascading emotions of grief and love for his family.

Wow what a instant classic. This movie was excellent and filled with great jump scares and kills. My favorite being a bathroom scene. The story,direction and character's were great. The little devil child is played brilliantly and the special effects were on point. These are the types of movies we need in the horror genre. I love the way the movie ends!!!!!!! The more jump scares the better in my opinion. There's not much else to say except I highly recommend you check this movie out. It's one of the best of the year in the horror genre and in my top 5 horror movies so far this year.
Saw this at the 2023 Sundance Film Festival.

A visually stunning and glamorous film. It follows a simple yet touching story through the eyes of the broken girl Shenxiu and a troubled man Nanhe. It revolves around the sea and the quest for a long lost destination. The first half of the film takes viewes into the universe. The last couple of scenes are tear-jerkers, when the ending song rose I just sit there and let myself immersed in the story. It's a story about pain and healing, sacrifice and salvation. Yet the dialogues in the film could be more refined and the first half plot is relatively weak. It could resonate with people fighting depression, anyway it's worth watching.

As chinese movie this art piece does not qualify as anime and does not follow amerian animation traditions as well, it stands on its own. The animations and visuals are stunning and really something new, but with a downside for me: for some bizarre reason they added massive "action camera shaking" over a majority of scenes (which gives these scenes the feeling of "shaky handheld camera"), combined with many super fast cuts. This combination has the potential to spoil the experience for some people - I really disliked this aspect.
Actually, I want to give 6 points, and the extra 1 point is for the efforts of Chinese anime.

The color matching is breathtakingly amazing, and the animation technology is at the forefront of the whole industry. The effect of this anime makes me cry, but sadly that's all there is. The movie has all the astonishing visual effects but it is too much for ONE movie. There's some scenes that is totally unnecessary, watching these incredible frames all the time is just making me feel tired and even disgusted. The director wants to show his talent so badly and it's like he put all the things that he have studied. The pace of the story drags on because of these scenes. Also, I cant understand what this movie is about in the first 1 hour. It seems like it is talking about a depressed girl is dying and the whole movie is about her dreams, but it is too unreasonable that most of the audiences can't understand. Anyway, it's a pity that this movie could have a higher rate.

Unlike many mainstream movie productions, the appreciation of Deep Sea requires a holistic lens. Borrowing from contemporary psychiatric literature, the film tells a story of hope, despair, and the rebirth of a little girl who is undergoing major setbacks in life.
Managed to catch this one at the 2023 Tribeca Film Festival.

Maybe the movie itself has many flaws, but I am still very surprised to have such a domestic animation movie. The picture is very delicate, the emotion is very rich, and the particle ink special effects are also very sincere, which is a very good movie-watching experience. Domestic films always like to use traditional myths as themes, and it is difficult to break through with new themes, especially the portrayal of inner emotions, which is unique, full of novelty, and far-reaching. I really admire the courage of director Tian Xiaopeng. I also look forward to more and better domestic animation films appearing.

The assessment of Deep Sea is similar to the general evaluation of a Chinese product. A foreign product is copied without any prior preparation or experience and attempts, or rather attempts, to commercially upgrade it for the market. Favourable location conditions meet more or less naive component juggling in this respect. The result is a good product at first glance, which looks really attractive on the outside in terms of market technology, but on closer inspection quickly reveals content of little value, a work that will not stand the test of time.

(85/100 - Excellent) "Deep Sea" in the character story through the elaborate setting and excellent visual art effect guidance, for the final act of the core explosion provides a strong expression."Deep Sea" is intoxicating in its beauty and penetrating in its depth. With its deep story and extraordinary audio-visual immersion, "Deep Sea" is a new milestone for Chinese animated films. Its technical inspiration also contributes to world animation.

This Chinese movie is so beautiful, filled with vibrant colours and top notch animation, I was so invested in the story and the atmospheric environment of this movie, the character design is so unique and weird, the cgi and vfx are so beautiful, even the rain looks like something from the dream, it's like the whole movies is inspired by lucid dreams, I was really glad I watched this movies, I have watched so many Chinese animated movies but, this one has some of the best colour palette, the story is very emotional and quite effective by the end, over I enjoyed the movie and hope to see more work like this in the future.

I was basically forced to watch this (i left my two brothers to play football in a mall and this was the only movie I could enter since all the others weren't close to my timing) It seemed okay I was attracted by the thumbnail, but oh boy how I was wrong , no disrespect or offense this is basically just my own based opinion. I hated every single second of it , the animation , the plot , the storyline is all so rushed and fast forwarded in an almost nauseating way, to the point where I fell asleep and there was not a single soul in the movies even watching (that's how bad it was) Everytime I dared to look I find myself wanting to throw up and just die.

The Deep Sea with its stunning particle effects, moving story content, in the Spring Festival stalls can be a flood of power to defeat the wandering earth 2 and full of red works, in recent years of animation competition can also be a flood of power to defeat thousands of horses, from the special effects or the core of the story are very heart, personally think is really the best Chinese animation film in recent years, breakthrough technology also breakthrough my heart defense, very moving film, although there are some flaws but the flaw does not cover up, I hope the audience can really quiet to watch it with heart, it deserves a better box office.

Almost all animated films in the past have a villain that needs to be defeated by the main character. Only by defeating the monster can one grow up and become a hero. This film breaks away from such a traditional paradigm. It focuses on a 9-year-old introverted girl, trying to describe her inner world with an extremely gorgeous color. It looks like she fell into a fairytale, surreal world with magic. Colors and darkness just like dreams and reality. Combining with heartwarming music, it unleashes a powerful emotional impact. I believe this film is of great significance for the development of children's mental health.

Colorful and highly saturated visuals often appear tacky, but "Deep Sea" is not one of them. The flow of various lights and watercolor hues, creates a strong visual impact. Each frame is like a world-renowned painting that immerse audiences in a beautiful world. The last twenty minutes of the story are tear-jerking, as many details and clues from the earlier part of the story suddenly become clear. Although I haven't experienced the same thing, I've heard from friends who have had similar experiences and can empathize with their tears. This is a story about self-healing and growth, and it's been a long time since a film has touched me so deeply. It may be difficult for young children to understand, so it's recommended that parents watch it with them and guide them through it. I strongly recommend this work to all adults, as it provides a delightful visual experience and provokes empathy and insightful thinking.
Giving this a 8/ 10

This is a film that on the surface looks like a storyline that borrows from "Spirited Away", and delves into the theme of fantasy, but once you cross a few thresholds of the movie you will likely start to realise that it is not so simple.

One of the strong immediate impressions of this film is the incredible beauty of the images and art, with the incredibly detailed processing of shadows and lighting. The unique use of particle effects also shows the charm of ink painting. The use of shocking story material, while avoiding many of the legends commonly used by domestic animated films, chose to focus on the impact of depression sufferers and family restructuring on children, paying full attention to the humanistic side.

No pun intended - and nothing to do with the horror action movie you may think about (Deep Blue Sea) ... or that I may have ... put in your mind. Also note that there are no sharks here - there are many other (sea) animals in this though.

I am currently crying so hard right now. This is seriously the most beautiful, well put together story ever. I can't believe how magical this movie was. The marvelous animation truly made me shed a tear. And especially the ending, that part was just so truly heart touching, words cannot describe the series of emotions I felt. I absolutely loved the climax it had insanely excellent detail. Oh, and we can't forget the conclusion. The conclusion was the greatest and saddest conclusion I have ever seen. Thank you so much Tian Xiao Peng for creating this absolute masterpiece. This is essentially the most important masterpiece of film history. It is a tragedy that this film is so underrated...this transcendent emotional experience will be inaccessible for most. It beautifully encapsulates the human struggle to its basics; suffering, happiness, loss, and despair. It connects with the characters within the viewers, individuals suppressed within our own subconscious. It stays vibrant, fresh, and revolutionizes the art of storytelling and filmmaking while making a damn of statement on what it means to be human. Entertaining, gripping, and simply exhilarating. This might be the most impactful piece of art I've come across in my life, and I'm definitely coming back to it in the near future to study it more deeply. It's an absolute masterpiece of a film. It absolutely moved my soul, and I don't think I can ever be the same. This incredible movie has changed my entire mental state, I am now at peace with who I am and what I will be doing later in my life. I have let go of the past and now I cherish all the little things in life. The animation, music and everything can be heard, tasted, seen, and felt from the screen. You can really tell that the people who worked on this film really poured their heart and soul into producing this. I definitely recommend watching this true piece of modern art. 10/10.

No pun intended - also the concept (of the website) has worked before ... even if it came crashing down at the end of the first movie. It's been a while so maybe you are not entirely familiar with it anymore ... but I do think the introduction to the movie and the short ... let's call it recap is working wonders.

Celine Song, in her directorial debut, makes a film whose story has little to do with the usual "movies." Past Lives is true, it is not the usual love story. It is not the usual movie love story. But it is more, because it is real, because it is true, because it is drawn from the living experience of the director. And in one way in the other, all of our lives are movies, only thanks to cinema we have the power to give a different development or ending to those stories. Instead, Song chose, bravely, to be true to what seemingly seems like a "trivial" love story of two people who are separated as children and meet again after 20 years by choice and not by chance. Two people who in the generality of their life stories, look at each other, scrutinize each other and love each other. It is a story made of silences, from which the thoughts of the two protagonists arise and arrive. It is a story made of glances and behind those glances are all the unspoken words, all those emotions that words would not render. Past Lives works because it is not what one expects from a film love story. It is real life.

I felt like this film touched on so many subtle, unsaid things between people: love that's lost because two people don't know how to/don't want to prioritize it, the convenience of being in some relationships, the feeling like you're saying something just because you think it's the right thing to say (especially around the people that you think need to hear it) when deep down it doesn't feel like the truth whatsoever, and going along with something because you've already committed to it instead of doing it because you want to do it. I know that's vague, but I didn't want to spoil anything, but maybe once you've seen it you'll know what I mean. It was all handled so beautifully and had such heartbreakingly sincere human experiences. I think it's safe to say that in the end, we have no effing idea what we are doing and how it will turn out, but we just hope it's the right decision in the moment.
And first-time director Celine Song has created one of these. It's a masterpiece of deeply genuine human emotion. And that masterpiece is Past Lives.
They say that the best kisses, the best loves, the best love stories are those that never happened, those that are idealized and remain in fantasy. Past Lives is that.

Here is a film that looks nothing, offers a beautiful evening, full of sincerity and missed opportunity. Very well played and an irreproachable aesthetic, hard not to be touched by this feeling, that we all knew one day.

The wind, the leaves, the streets, the towers; everything exists with a supple glow. There's a love for environment behind the camera, where director Celine Song stands, telling her story. Kirchner, her cinematographer, lends immense craft to the film's 35mm scenery. Nora, Hae Sung, Arthur; the three central characters are handled with wonderful grace. They easily communicate complex emotion. They're likable, and they're relatable. New York City, Seoul; I hardly know either of them practically, but now I feel like I do, in some intimate way. These two cities are dearly loved. Longing; what did you think of when you finished this film?

Now here's a story that has something for us all, if you consider all the past events and things that went before, all the options, permutations, that could have ended in relations, outcomes, futures, roads untaken, that then fall. As Jung Hae Sung and Nora meet as kids, there's a connection but then adios she bids, moving to the USA, kimchi days are left astray, different plays shape different folks - the lives they've lived. Correspondence over time keeps thoughts reflective, then meeting up creates a kind of retrospective, what could have been, and what could be, things preordained, but choice is free, quite intriguing, but it rests on your perspective.

I saw the trailer to "Past Lives" before a showing of "Master Gardener," and immediately knew I wanted to see it. I have an affinity for Asian cinema, but more than that, the concept of past lovers reconnecting after decades made for an intriguing premise, one that I had to see unfold on the big screen. And after seeing it unfold (on the big screen), I honestly can't tell how I feel about "Past Lives," which, I guess, means it left me feeling kind of cold.

Difficult to write too much about this film who offers a nice , large fist of emotions. The story itself is simple and offers minimum surprises. The 1940 decade romance air is honest, clear and, sure, in special sense, comfortable.
It's clear I am in a minority, but I didn't enjoy this very much.
Slow moving, boring, and average. I'm having a hard time understanding the overwhelmingly positive reviews. Interesting look at relationships I guess but not really interesting at the same time.
One of the rare movie sequels that made me laugh as much as the first one!

In the realm of comedies, Alibi.com 2 stands out as a refreshing gem, surpassing many of its American counterparts with its clever wit and absence of crude toilet humor. This French sequel, released in 2023, continues the story of Greg, now engaged to Flo, as he navigates the introduction of his eccentric family to his beloved. To shield Flo from the truth about his family's unconventional ways, Greg revives his alibi agency, fabricating a set of fake parents for her.

I confess. I surrender. My shameful tastes - the ones I struggle to admit - are Philippe Lacheau films. It's when I see Julien Arruti running with a toilet seat bolted to his arse, Tarek Boudali wriggling in a teddy-bear suit worn backwards (with the tail doing what you think it does), or Lacheau himself fighting Didier Bourdon naked, that I realise I am, definitively, a big dumb beauf.

I was lucky enough to see an early screening of a "not quite finished" version of this film. Shot In the Arm," in Las Vegas in late 2022. I was blown away, immediately knowing at least a dozen friends I'd drag to see it. The film came about in the most unusual and amazing way. In the hands of someone other than Academy Award nominated documentary filmmaker Scott Hamilton Kennedy, I doubt it would have survived. But due to his brilliant ability to pivot, and switch directions when he suddenly found the story rapidly changing in real-time, audiences are going to see something extraordinary. If you've heard stories or suspect you know the truth behind vaccines, you must see this film. It is truly amazing.

I have seen Sky is Pink, the movie based on Aisha's life. But this documentary is just so much more! There are certain parts of the documentary that are so touching, that it feels as if you can touch and feel what Aisha's parents must be going through and what Aisha must be going through. Having never experienced a loss of a loved one, this shook me to the core and brought me so close to what a loss would feel like and made me experience grief, even though it's not mine. Aisha was so expressive with her writing and her art that it helps you peak into her heart and soul and forces you to empathise with her. God bless her beautiful soul. Both Aditi and Niren pour out their souls in this documentary and take us on their journey with Aisha from her birth to the very last moments of her life with brutal honesty and courage.

Nobody should pass a comment before seeing a movie. It's an absolutely raw and truthful story that needs to be told not just to emote but to help others on a similar journey. A must watch. Bless Aditi and Niren and Ishan for giving their whole and more for Aisha. The movie is very cathartic and poignant. The Sky is Pink though well made wasn't able to show the emotion and the changing emotions of both Aisha and the parents. I particularly love her love story and that they shared it was wonderful. In her short life, she experienced all emotions from fear and anger to so much love and joy and I look forward to reading her book.

I have not watched this so I am giving a neutral rating. But.. how many times will this family tell this story??? A whole movie wasn't enough??? They want to milk her death even more? This is no more about spreading awareness. The movie and other countless interviews done by her family already did that. So whats the purpose of this story to be told again for the nth time???? Money??? I don't understand. Do they want people to once again feel sad for them? Or once again say oh wow what a brave girl??? Like what do they want to achieve thats not already done?? Not going to watch this because there are many other more important stories that deserve our time. Other kids who have died. Other families that have suffered and no one listens to them because no one is making movies about them. This family needs to take a break!

review_text: Though I had already watched several videos on the history of the Bible including feature length films, I was pleasantly surprised to learn many new things from this documentary.

This documentary has been the best that I have seen on the King James Bible. It uses a ton of scripture mixed with historical facts. Professionally made with excellent editing and dynamic narrating. It's not too long or too short but just right. This is a great addition to a short list of documentaries on this subject. Whether or not you agree with the independent fundamental Baptist beliefs, this documentary provides enough historical data to show how the King James Bible has been attacked and the events that transpired before it's inception. The historical facts in of itself are compelling but the Bible says "faith cometh by hearing and hearing by the word of God".

This film really inspired me to learn more about the history of the Bible and why the King James Bible is the preserved word of God in English for use today. I especially enjoyed learning about the men who hazarded their lives for people to be able to read a Bible and specifically to have the correct words of God. Brave men like William Tyndale are an encouragement to live by faith and I truly enjoyed how his death was significantly used to provoke other men to deliver us the Bible we have today. Additionally, the information about how the critical text is not superior to the received text was vital to helping people understand why modern Bibles are not faithful translations of the preserved Greek and Hebrew texts.

This is a documentary that I got the opportunity to check out thanks to Kim from Dominion3. The doc is from Level 33 Entertainment. I've seen work from them in horror. Now this doesn't fall into that genre. There are horrific things that come from the subject here. I'm going to trend lightly and try to keep my personal beliefs to a minimum. Below is the synopsis as to why:

Plan C was enthusiastically received in its Texas Premiere at the SXSW Film Festival. This film documents the increasingly Kafkaesque world of abortion access in which the right to abortion access has been increasingly restricted - and nowhere more than here in Texas. Plan C focuses in on the courageous efforts of activists to provide access to abortion pills in states where the medical procedures are now increasingly difficult to attain. This is a case where what is right may not be the same as what is legal. And the laws restricting abortion are inherently classist and racist, because low-income women often lack the means to travel to other states to attain the procedure at a medical facility. This is a courageous film of doctors and activists standing up to unjust citizens through acts of civil disobedience. The film captures their struggle for justice against laws that seem to have come out of the Handmaiden's Tale. Everyone who is concerned about reproductive justice should see this film.
Enrapturing and emotionally charged, 'Plan C' is a compelling testament to the resilience and unwavering determination of individuals striving to broaden access to crucial healthcare services.

title: Domino 23: Gli ultimi non saranno i primi
The Quest Get Back Your Ex

review_text: Ok, so there are loads of pretty boy-band type actors wandering around here - occasionally in various states of (pixellated) undress, but otherwise this is all a rather messy and unfunny crime caper that sees a group of private security lads and one of the would-be robbers head into the jungle to try to recover some missing jewels (pinched by one of their own number - "Jelly" (Kaho Hung) - who is making for the border). Along the way, they alight on some rather feisty commune-dwellers who can be quite efficient with a pitch fork whilst all the time being pursued by the folks who want the jewels and by a mysterious apparition, too. Can they catch up with and apprehend their erstwhile pal in time? At times the visual nature of their antics and the humour wouldn't look out of place in a bad Laurel and Hardy movie and though the eye candy carries it for the first half hour, the rest of it is all rather silly and forgettable. There is just too much random activity and too many off-the-wall characterisations to keep it watchable for any longer. If I'm being honest - the word puerile springs to mind.

I am Sabri Yunus's fan, become his fan after fall in love with Pok Ya Cong Codei series and Butak. When this movie is announced, I have a big expectation because Butak is great. So I hope Duan is better. But, if you already watch a lot of his work that involve Kelantanese traditional play and gangsterisme. Yeah, its the same thing. The idea is good but the execution is still at the level of his television's work. For example, this movie have a lot of fighting scene. I know this production maybe cannot afford Yayan Ruhian, Iko Uwais and Cecep Arif Rahman coreography but we have Areel Abu Bakar who make quite similar international level action in Geran so you can use him for fighting action sequence. The other problem is, too many character, for those who never watch Sabri Yunus's television work, might feel why he include so many people. But I understand because all of them is his regular cast, I think its quite unnecessary because movie is one-shot so you need to focus on the main character and main storyline. However, I still like it but I guess kelantanese will love this movie more. If Kelantan have cinema, this movie will be surely box office there.
Gerald, with an R-Rah Grabs Your Heart!

This movie right here Gerald's Hands is an amazing movie for all ages. You can tell the passion and hard work that went into this movie from beginning to the end. Naz Pankey and Andrew McAllister are a force to be reckoned with from the writing to the acting. The writing is superb it tells the story of Gerald an Autistic young man who strives to live in a world that doesn't see him like others see him. This movie will make you laugh and make you cry. You better grab your tissues. This movie will bless you. The cast is talented and amazing. You will not be disappointed. This is a movie that we need.

Gerald's Hands is by far one of the most compelling films I've seen a long time. This is a film that will make you cry, laugh, love, and smile. It was brilliantly written, and the actors... whew... breathtaking and phenomenal! I LOVE THIS MOVIE, and my sons love it too (they especially love Gerald)! As a mother who has a child with autism, it never occurred to me what life would be like for an adult with autism, until watching Gerald's Hands. This movie not only shares awareness as it pertains to autism, but it reminds us that we all deserve to be loved. Please take a moment to watch this film, I promise you will love it, the way my family and I did!

As a social worker that has worked with those who are on the autism spectrum, I am happy to write a very positive review for the film, Gerald's Hands. The film is not only excellent as far as the actors in the film, particularly Andrew R. McCallister, who plays Gerald, but also in the positive image that the film portrays about those that have dedicated their life in supporting and encouraging and helping those that are young and old who are similar to Gerald.

Gerald's Hands was an incredible movie. It was an aspiring movie that touched my heart in many ways. Most people in their lives will experience the hardships of bullying. This movie shows that but it goes a step further and shows you more Regarding this conflict.

This movie is so touching! I think there needs to be more movies like this that really touch on issues in communities that would not ordinarily get attention. In this movie I see it opening up a dialogue and some much needed eye opening to issues like bullying and domestic violence and more importantly the issue of loss and grief. Thank you for this. The world will thank you for this. I highly recommend this to any lover of movies and any lover of life and inspirational stories in real life. Thank you thank you thank you! This touched home for me bringing up so many feelings and memories. #IamGeraldToo.

The spirit of God is present in this movie. Gerald's Hands will touch you deeply. It will make you feel human. I cried watching it. Your heart will feel for the character Gerald in a special way because special people do extraordinary things. It's no surprise because the creator Nadira Pankey and the star Andrew R. McCallister are extraordinary people. From watching this movie, I hope that more people will lead with kindness, and understand that being autistic isn't a disability. It's a superpower! Gerald's Hands is a movie about humanity and love. It's a movie combating bullying. This is a movie that celebrates good over evil, right over wrong. It's a story that highlights a superhero in Gerald. We are all superheroes, and we are all capable of being good people. Vote for Gerald and watch it on Tubi because it's the right thing to do, plus it's free. : )

As a Belgian I'm always curious about the movies from my country, knowing we never have a Hollywood budget so the story has to be really good to stand out. Every now and then there's such a movie, unfortunately Ida isn't one of them. The pace of the movie is too slow and that has a negative effect on the quality. There's some tension building at one point, that worked mostly because of the good soundtrack, but the actual thriller or horror part was just too weak because of the wrong decision-making by the character. There is no reason why a young and healthy woman couldn't push that old lady to the floor and then just outrun her. There are plenty of scenes like that that make the movie just mediocre. Writer/director Brandon Gotto should have done better, even with a low budget.

This is why I love indie flicks. "Break Glass" has all the elements that make this genre near and dear to my heart. It features a lineup of relatively unknown actors who all turn in decent performances. It also is well written, with some witty dialogue and a compelling storyline. And you can definitely tell it was made on limited budget. But the director certainly made the best of it.

This poignant tale of love, loss, and longing is a masterful exploration of the human heart. Teru's story is a gut-wrenching reminder of the devastating power of grief, but also a testament to the resilience of the human spirit.

Mor ve Ã–tesi (Purple and Beyond). We, the rock music lovers of Turkey, always watched such things from foreign singers or groups. Mor ve Ã–tesi is a first in Turkey, and they succeeded without falling into mediocrity and without getting bored, they turned the concert into a nice movie... Congratulations from the heart.

I couldn't finish this one. One could argue that the copious profanity and violence was necessary for the plot, but the movie self-consciously focuses on those to the exclusion of better plot and character development.

I saw Motel Drive at the Tucson international film festival. It's a wonderful movie with an honest and touching view of life for people with significant housing, addiction and other challenges. The movie provides both a candid view of the struggles and challenges these people face/endure as well as showing a very human portrait of a few of these individuals over the course of approximately 9 years.
Excellent film portraying the plight of families and individuals struggling with housing, addiction, and financial insecurity.

review_text: The story line off this film is actually really good, and it's the only reason I watched the whole way through. The leads acting wasn't the worst I've seen but the friend... Wow... His tone off voice didn't change once, not to mention the huge delays between words like he was reading off a script in front off him. The other huge problem is that the graphics special effects and cgi are the 2nd worse I've ever seen and I've watched some poor films. It's essentially all cgi, there are people floating as they walk, gaps in the frame like a really bad photoshop job, I'm pretty sure this was filmed all in one room and the actors were never in that room together as can be seen in the few shots that they 'appear together' as you can see the overlay.
Not sure why I watched this. Not a good sign for a horror anthology when you nod off to sleep half way through.

The fourth cinematic installment of the notorious Italian YouTuber duo, "Me contro Te - Missione Giungla," is an odyssey that, unfortunately, gets lost in an endless dÃ©jÃ  vu. Directed by Gianluca Leuzzi, the film, while reflecting the duo's established formula, fails to evolve beyond the YouTube children's entertainment brand. The plot is a predictable blend of situations already exploited in previous chapters: LuÃ¬ and SofÃ¬, fresh from an adventure in Ancient Egypt, find themselves once again having to save the world. This time, a magical source in the jungle is in danger, but the feeling of dÃ©jÃ  vu is unavoidable. The film follows the usual pattern: festive atmosphere, hidden danger, race against time, all seasoned with musical moments and comedic numbers. However, "Missione Giungla" shows its struggle within the first ten minutes. The plot is thin, and the acting barely decent, often overshadowed by moments of excessive exaggeration. The attempt to embrace the adventure genre is ineffective, with set design and visual effects that seem to come from a YouTube video, but stretched to reach feature-length. The lead duo, Luigi Calagna and Sofia Scalia, with their childish voices, seem trapped in a format that fails to evolve. The predictable plot, TikTok-style dances, and excessive use of plastic effects turn the cinematic experience into a simulation of happiness. While the saga's success can be attributed to children's immunity to dÃ©jÃ  vu, "Missione Giungla" seems more like an attempt to exploit the brand than a true step forward. The film represents a necessary economic chapter but gets lost in the inability to innovate and offer quality entertainment for new generations. In conclusion, "Me contro Te - Missione Giungla" may awaken nostalgia for the nineties, but it fails to take the couple's cinematic experience to new heights. An adventure that, unfortunately, announces the fifth film, maintaining the formula but sacrificing the opportunity for growth.

review_text: The film starts with a very long conversation that put me off straight away. I didn't last more then ten minutes. The dialogue is cringe and not realistic, if it had the intention of intriguing the audience well, it definitely did not work with me.

Knowing all that went on behind the scenes with this film, I think the end product isn't too bad. There are some nice ideas in there and I liked the slow burn feel of it. Not sure about the acting in places from all parties and found myself turning the volume down a couple of times before the whining was getting annoying. I can't help but think what would happen if the same film was made with a bigger budget though. Also found the end to be quite abrupt after all the build up but again there were some nice ideas there.

The main girl wasn't too bad but either than that it was a standard student looking film. Not much skill set was provided for this film and I'm not looking forward to anymore Matt Shaw films. Just boring for what it was trying to do. Sorry Matt and team! Maybe next time!

Despite the beautiful and breathtaking animation, the amazing acting, the heartbreaking score, and the absolute comedic genius, that is not the reason why I love this. It is not because I love all of Jack Mularski's works either. It is because I FINALLY FEEL SEEN IN A MOVIE!!!

review_text: IT WAS THE GREATEST MOVIE ABOUT ENGLISH 4 I'VE EVER WATCHED!!!

Sophie's rules is a touching movie. It is nice to see a movie that shows love and kindness in the world for people, especially when they are lost from tragedy, addiction or illness. I found it very heartwarming that they helped each other, looked out for each other and ultimately found peace within themselves.

With an outspoken frenemy and unknown enemies. Osoronga is the story of a young man who is told he will be killed in 21 days by witches. Everywhere he turned to for help advise the same thing...Run Run Run for your life. Sometimes, you never know where battles stem from. Sometimes, loved ones take your battles on your behalf, they go finding revenge on your behalf without knowing full details of issues. With Voices in his head, strange appearances in his mind, frustration and suicide thoughts envelopes him. With a praying mum and fortification from the underworld, victory seems to be near.... Let me stop here to avoid spilling it all out.
Movies frequently tell the stories of lone heroes who overcome troubles on their own.

This is a story of how human hardships can bring everyone together! Directors, Christina Tsialtas and Maritza Brikisak did an excellent job illustrating each character's pain and vulnerability. The writing was on point. The motley crew of characters makes for great storytelling. You get a inside look into each character's mind. The cast was well assembled. The storyline kept your interest throughout the entire movie. The menagerie of personalities made for an interesting and unpredictable movie. You have to watch until the end to understand how everyone comes together for the better good. This is a must see!

The Movie delicately portrays true stories that evoke reflection and introspection. Director Christina Tsialtas (and the team) masterfully weaves together these real life accounts to create a thought provoking film that reminds us that these characters and incidents could easily be our own. With a focus on positivity and hope, the film encourages us to consider whether we are "lucky" or "strong" enough to find salvation in both life's struggles and triumphs.

Escape your reality when you need to face it head on . Its a long road to recovery. It is a long road to recovery. Its a disease and people need to treat it that way which ties to mental health. This film made one see that even tho you seem good one day you can you be a huge mess the day. The ache and need is real and youre haunted by the need to stop but the devil of addiction rides you hard and wont let you be. People try to escape reality but you cannot escape it. You think you can. You cant. 'Dont judge me egg man' , hit hard. Judgement is real. Film is good i think if you have the means for bigger production these stories are real. Little girly wants to fit in one you look good next day you look like the demons are riding you. I just know what i like. This hurts a bit. And i like it.

Great film, would strongly recommend. This film pulled at my heart strings, opened my mind and kept me fully engaged, eager to see what was going to happen next! The story line was creative and the characters each had a relatable quality that gave me a feeling of empathy and compassion. Each character was unique and interesting and it was clear these were experienced actors as they each nailed their individual roles. The writers and directors did an effective job of evoking many different emotions from from sympathy to optimism to humor. I would also recommend this film for a broad audience - good work!

Touching threads of folks who are struggling being given a supposed temporary safety zone. Broken systems around the works are not able to care for people they govern. Veterans are to be treated with dignity and respect not forgotten. Sophie imposes rules and she has to follow them, also while making it possible for her to help people in need. PTSD, anxiety, panic attacks, grief mental anguish of all kinds are often not understandable can lead to different outcomes. This is a descent touching film that hits the heart and has a cute finish. Comedy drama? More drama and not so much comedy. I recommend this.

Directors Christina Tsialtas and Maritza Brikisak did a awesome job portraying the hardships of the characters. Most horror fans already know Maritza, who's also the leading actress in the movie, from cult movies like The Lurking Man, she shows her versatility here. The cinematography of Christina Tsialtas makes the atmosphere of the film dreamlike and beautiful. What makes the movie even more memorable is that it is very unpredictable, there are lots of twists and turns, action and even violence. So even though the main theme, at least for me, is goodness and helping each other out, the surprises and the action never stop.

Never heard of these Directors or writers, understandable since it's an independent film. Stories were strong ( PTSD felt real) and in some cases heart wrenching; would of liked to know more in the sub plots, there are some unknowns that needed more or not so rushed . Story felt almost docudrama ish, which is why more background on sub plots would have heightened the ending. I appreciate the idea of the homeless shelter, although it felt upscale ish, the idea appealed to me. The actors were believable and well done with they're portrayals. Sophie felt stern yet caring leading the group of past/ current members of her house. Cinematography captured the actors in their vulnerable portrayals and I really enjoyed the outdoor scenes. All in all good work on the collaboration melding a few into one.

This is a very heartfelt film. In fact the film is sprinkled with such lovely heartfelt moments,and sad onesI have to say it kept me engaged the whole time, wondering what happens next. It was nice to see that there are still people in this world who care for others in.a time of need. It's also brings to light to addiction you need help and also want the help to get better. It's more of a disease than addiction. Definitely a must seen film to watch. To the directors Christina Tsialtas and Maritsa Brikisak on an excellent job on this film, especially being on a low budget film. I was also glad to see that Christina Tsialtas and Maritsa Brikisak did a great job directing the characters .

This film advocates all that stand for in life. I didn't expect to end up cryin at the end of it the way I did. A part of me cried because I wish I had somebody to help me through my ptsd and my alcoholic trembles amd black outs and difficult times when I thought I am alone. Somebody to talk to when I lost everything. I struggle to this day I am 266 days sober. The film showed harsh realities in a hard world. Ups and downs can happen. One day smiling next day down in the dumps. Sophie needs rules that end up broken and keep them. Harsh realities is so many homeless who don't have a chance. Die in the cold no food no roof to sleep under. Beautiful film loss is real.

An independent "small budget" film that has something big to say about the people who find themselves lost, and considered collateral damage in a society that knows the price of everything, but the value of nothing. From a mother who has a son in the military go MIA, and refuses to believe he's actually gone, and by holding on to that belief, becomes estranged from her husband and friends. She meets the rest of the characters, all broken in different ways. Some are in physical danger, all are in emotional turmoil. But they all have the good fortune of meeting Sophie. She knows that the "official" programs can be insufficient, and sets up a home/shelter to let these people heal. It's an emotional journey for all. In summary, this film will put you in touch with your humanity. I feel enriched after watching it.
I liked it, a moving film that gives nice positive vibes. Different moments were pretty exciting.

Moving film about a retired nurse helping people who seem to be forgotten and need help. It concludes with a positive finish filled with struggles while trying to keep going. All characters showed us pain and smiles, much like life. Fear can be overcome, hardships can still have a nice ending, and we all live life and death happens to those we love. Directors Christina Tsialtas and Maritza Brikisak gave us a powerful look behind this pretty exterior that houses people in various forms of distress. Physical, mental anguish and abuse all played out well in the lives that reside in and out of this home hoping for something better. I highly recommend this heartwarming film.

I recently had the pleasure of watching Sophie Rules, and I must say that it is truly a gem of a film. The story revolves around Sophie, a retired nurse who transforms her home into a transition shelter. The movie beautifully explores the lives of a diverse group of people who seek refuge in the Cottonwood residence.

This little production had a slow start and built steam as it continued as it build layers for all the different people in the thread of stories. Directors Christina Tsialtas & Maritsa Brikisak gave us pain and fighting to survive in todays times in a color full company of humans. From married couple who are dealing with their sons disappearance to Sophie who seems like a tough as nails head of a home for transitioning from a group of people who each have their problems.

I thoroughly enjoyed this and earnestly recommend anyone and everyone watch it. I found it to be a heart-tugging storyline and was very moved by the crosses each of the characters was bearing and the realistic, though certainly not always positive manner with which each was confronting them.
I love this movie!

Sophie's Rules is one of the most heart warming films out there. There are a variety of storylines that each character brings, which ultimately provides viewers with an understanding of many different hardships and circumstances. Despite the very different back stories of the characters, the writers and producers did a great job at intertwining and connecting the characters to create a perfect, seamless storyline. The main takeaway message in my opinion was that there is always a light at the end of tunnel, and you don't need much to help another person. Would highly recommend watching this, especially in this day and age.

I really enjoyed Osoronga. Sure, the storyline might seem regular/ordinary at first glance, but the way it was told made all the difference. Ibrahim truly did something fresh with this one. The plot took unexpected turns-it wasn't the predictable ride I assumed it would be.

Great re-imagination of an old story with beautiful shots and colors. Honest and artistic voice in a unique perspective. It also contains thematic references about race and colonialism examined in great ways. The color scheme is really what I loved about the film. I saw it at IFFR and I think the selection is very much in tune with the tastes of the festival in boundary pushing cinema that makes people challenge their usual visions. If you like some films that make you see the world feel and think and visualize differently, this film gives a great chance to look at the old stories in a fresh new perspective. Recommend.

I enjoyed watching the ensemble cast in this heartwarming film. The way they found a "family" together and all supported each other was so nice to watch. Enjoyed watching "Sophie's" acting very much. Seemed quite authentic. She was very believable as an empathetic, kind, yet firm woman who runs the house. Christina Tsialtis and Maritzka Brikisak did a great job directing. I enjoyed the interwoven stories of the various characters. It definitely kept me interested and invested to see what would come of them. I felt satisfied by the ending, I like how it all wrapped up. I would definite recommend this movie to anyone.

Co-written by Marcus D. Spencer and Eduardo Castrillo and directed by Marcus D. Spencer, 'Who Needs It?' is a feature length comedy drama that stars Michael Grayson, Sherill Quinn, Felix Harry and Spencer himself.
OMG. This movie was so engaging. It captured my full attention. A must watch film.
The first few minutes aerial shots got me excited. Usually for indie films I'm not blown away before I meet the characters, but this time I was!

Story of a common man who end up combining the core people who belong to orchestra . ORCHESTRA MYSURU . It contains situational comedy which engages, love story which brings smile on your face , friendship which never ever betrays .RAGHU DIXIT comes again with a bang where lyrics are penned by Daali Dhananjaya . Poorna our comman man and Dileepraj as Naveen Star Naveen are our main characters who Chase their dreams and full fill them through music. Raghu Dixit once again proved with the background music not only background all songs are best tuned . Special mention to the singer Siddhartha Belmannu.

The sheer naturalness of this film disproves the notion that success is a selfish goal, which is what the filmmakers have achieved. More tales like this one, with their less showy presentation of what they have to say, should be told.

Being a Mysurean it was heart warming for me and at the same time absolutely fresh theme! Gandhinagar and its rich culture of orchestra was a huge revelation for me! Excellent performances from all the artists specially that of Poorna and Mahesh! Their chemistry was cute! The sublet encouragement of the senior photographer was touching. The positive power of social media, and inclusive growth was commendable! The wedding song and the final performance in Yuva Dasara was soulful. The movie could have been edited better and dialogues should have been sharper- the film was tad too long and picks up steam post 35 mins!
A must watch tale of underdog not to be missed on big screen. Its an experience one must not miss.
Watched on prime and I can say it's honest try by the makers of the movie.

Wonderfully made movie. Simple story presented very well. Lovely and cute movie with super perfect acting by all. Story is the main lead actor here and hence no 'overrated'', overacting' and 'ugly' scenes or dialogues. Every scene carries the story forward. It presents the story of every Orchestra musicians, layer by layer. No scene is out of place. No character is unwanted. Screenplay and dialogue is pure, simple and realistic. Music is lovely. 'Nadiyondu' is one of the best Kannada film songs in recent years. 'Haaduve' song gives goose bumps with its symphonic crescendo in the end. Raghu Dixit has done wonders with his music. Poorna as Poorna is closer to your heart and you feel for him despite his web of lies. Orchestra Mysuru is one of the cleanest and beautiful made in Kannada in recent years. Hats off to the team.
The film has been inspired by the lives of local music talent who went on to garner national and global recognition.

A brilliant display of orchestra and music. A story of an underdog who dreams of singing and performing in front of thousands. It has been inspired from the life story of Raghu Dixit & Naveen Sajju (Musicians). The story has been delightfully crafted by Sunil Mysuru (Director). His visionary skill has portrayed the struggling life of orchestra artists. Great performance by all actors who have carried their roles so perfectly. Story is carried through rollercoaster of emotions and presented beautifully with great music from Raghu Dixit Sir and Mind Blowing lyrics from Daali Dhananjay Sir.

Sunil Mysuru and team's ambitious project is honest to the core but gets tad bit pulled back by the slow narrative and long runtime which is close to 3hrs. Firmly aided by Raghu Dixit's music, the world of orchestra is well built and not to forget the support provided by Dileep Raj as Orchestra Star Naveen Raj. The research behind the world of orchestra completely shows as the makers claim it to be based on the real life experiences of Naveen Sajju and Raghu Dixit.
Feel sorry for the movie team as it couldn't stay in theatres for more time.

People who are associated with this movie in some way (or their friends and family) are giving it high ratings I guess. This movie is full of subpar performances. The characters are forgettable and totally slappable (because most of them are beyond annoying). The story is best suited for a short film.
Wonderful screen play and script. A must watch movie for all the youngsters who have crossed their path of struggle to achieve dreams.

Film scores well in most of the areas. To begin with the acting of Poornachandra , he is an absolute talent . His extraordinary skills will definitely take him to a greater heights. Rajalakshmi has done well too, but dubbing artist for rajalakshmi could have done better. Director has won first half by gluing audience to their seats. Second half too was equally good however, could have been cut short by 20 mins. Music scores well with meaningful lyrics , though not catchy. (Dum idre hodi) only song that registered. Definitely worth a watch to support our mysore talents sure to make big names...
As an ardent Orchestra fan right from my childhood days in the late 70s and 80s...I can relates to all the characters shown in this movie and their challenges and aspirations.

I am from mysore, I can relate the places and characters, The movie is original, simple with real emotions, it makes one realise that dreams are every humans right and chasing it needs a lot of dedication and effort along with talent, however with hard work, we need to to learn to enjoy the journey as well. The movie music is mesmerising, We are all a bit of musicians in our own way. We need to support good things in life. I am supporting mysore orchestra team with all love. Kudos to the team.

Becoming the Beckhams is actually a really fun and surprisingly engaging show. It mixes documentary-style storytelling with casual, back-and-forth commentary that keeps it informative without ever feeling dry or overly serious. From the way the show moves between interviews, archival footage, and personal anecdotes, it feels dynamic, giving viewers both context and entertainment in equal measure.

Alena: Anak Ratu Iblis is an Indonesian horror film that attempts to deliver a cinematic experience with ambitious visual effects. Directed by Sonu Samtani, the film showcases striking CGI elements, including a brutal opening scene and a vividly colored fantasy world. Some viewers appreciated this effort, describing it as a "fresh and amusing horror film to kick off 2023" .

title: Hao Are You
production_company: Hanfgarn & Ufer Film und TV Produktion

review_text: Don't believe all the 10 star reviews, they all look like they're made by the same person, and all of the reviewers have only ever reviewed this, the film is terrible, the acting is atrocious, I only watched this film after reading the great reviews and to see how fabulous the actress mentioned in a few of the glowing reviews was as I'd never heard of her before and was intrigued to see who she was. The acting is wooden throughout, I really don't understand why some of the other reviewers refer to the comedic timing as it was anything but timed, this is one of the worst films I've seen in a long while.

title: Aikatsu! 10th Story: Starway to the Future

review_text: I love this film. So much fun. Great performances and directing. Nicole Faraday is as wonderful as ever. ðŸ‘ ðŸ‘ I can't wait to watch it again.
Really fun film with great emotional impact and comedic timing from Nicole Faraday as the wronged wife.
Hilarious, great comedic film. The story is really great and the comedic timings are terrific. All actors involved performed exceptionally well.
What a great film. It is funny, preposterous and gripping with a superb cast, especially the incandescent Nicole Faraday. Great cameos from Jeremy Edwards and Nick Moran too.

The film keeps you on the edge of your seat as the situation keeps escalating! More and more memorable characters keep piling their weight on the already tense situation. Definitely would love to watch it again!
Captivating from start to end lots of twists and turns. Never laughed so much in my life.
Fantastic writting with some great dark comedic moments in there! Great casting too! Each of the cast were perfect for their parts!

title: Salazar, le Portugal Ã  quitte ou double

review_text: I was hyped to finally have a look behind the curtains of speedrunning.

I watched this very long documentary having no real interest or knowledge (or interest to gain knowledge of) Super Mario Brothers, which came out after I was done playing video games (I am glad Colecovision was mentioned here, which I grew up with)...

This film was was structured in a way difficult to convey what it means to speedrun it focuses on a speedrunner then goes to the game then goes back to the runner then talks about gdq. (despite having other speedrun charity events) Then it goes back talking about another runner then back to gdq. Having this pacing makes the film stuck in repetition like an essay trying to reach the word count, then the guy who narrates the film says he wants no attention yet gives himself the biggest ego stroke at the end which rubs me the wrong way. Overall this film I feels like it doesn't present it's topic well by adding multiple scenes which doesn't make sense or irrelevant at times which results in a complete mess of a documentary. The should have focused on one single topic of speedrunning (History of speedrunning or GDQ) and organized it in a way (chronological and etc.) that it is engaging for the viewers.
The featured players in this doc are unreal first off. Best in the world, crazy how they got them all in the same doc.

Super interesting with a lot of interviews of the greats! Definitely entertaining too because they show events as well. The ppl behind this obvz put in a lot of effort or are gamers themselves because they went into some info and coverage that is specific and important for speed running so koodos for bringing this into the light more. Alotta ppl don't really know much about speed running and the people behind it and the amazing things they've done and the skill it takes so I'm definitely hoping this will kinda ignite more people to get involved and lookinto it and help it get bigger. Stoked for this stuff to get arena level big!
An incredibly educational and good-natured documentary that doesn't require exaggerated rivalries or antagonists to tell a coherent story.

As a student on a film school this production really surprised me. I heard it was made by amateurs so I expected it to be quite a bad film. The dialogue isn't always on top. Almost all shots of this film are quite well made, of course there are a few weird shots here and there but most of them worked. I noticied nothing weird with the editing in this movie aswell. For amateurs production this movie is very well made. I was honsetly very impressed they managed to pull it off so well as they did. Good job. Well the story may not be that top notch but it isn't really boring. I can also have bias in favour of this film because my cousins are in this one. I feel like this movie highlights an important and forgotten event in Swedish history.

title: Greybeard: The Man, the Myth, the Mississippi
Stone Flowers: Songs of Hope and Defiance
Return to the Theatre of Terror
The Dark Possesion curse of evil

review_text: Always on the lookout for a decent horror anthology that I haven't seen, I ran across this title somewhere and decided to give it 10 minutes to win me over. After 10 minutes, it was obvious that, unlike so many excretable horror anthologies out there, that this was a professional and talented production, so I kept watching.

For a B-movie, the production values were pretty good, as was the acting and music. The stories, however, were mostly too long and drawn out, with the exception of the first and last one, which was my favorite. I fast-forwarded through some of them. In my opinion, most of them are more like dramas than horror, with the exception of the longest one. I guessed what was going to happen in that one, though, so the ending didn't shock me. I would say these are more comparable to an Alfred Hitchcock Presents type of storyline. I did like the story ideas; they just weren't actually very scary.
The segments go on FOR EV ER. FOR. EV. ER. Especially the second one. Plots are very basic and predictable, nothing new here to write home about (not going to "spoil" them for you).

I love scary movies! I love anthologies! I love the indomitable spirit of Independent film and filmmakers! The team at Theatre of Terror have expertly crafted a feature that displays the tremendous talents of the New Jersey horror film community and wonderfully talented actors of the unique New York/New Jersey film scene! Return to Theatre looks great, sounds great and feels great! Like watching your favorite horror television classics like Twilight Zone, Tales From The Darkside or Outer Limits. Director Thomas Ryan and his team hit a fun and scary home run! A MUST-SEE for lovers of classic horror cinema blended perfectly with late night Sci-Fi television fun!

Tom Ryan did it again with Return To The Theatre of Terror. In his second collection of short stories, we are taken on another trip with the consequences of time travel in the Sothsayer to an infection that goes out of controlled in Splinter with paranormal investigations with acts of self righteousness in Haunted to a boy finding a new toy that fell from the skies in Robot.

I really enjoyed these films very much gave me a creepshow vibe very well written and the acting was top notch. I met Tom at a Horror Convention along with Jason great bunch of guys and i like that it took place in jersey A must see.i look forward to more of his movies Iam definitely a horror fan.it brings me back to alot of the 80's horror not to much gore! It keeps you wanting more i reall y cant wait too see whats next! If i was going to do a film horror is definitely the route i would go especially when it has you at the edge of your seats. Like these films did i was always into like the Twilight Zone which these movies remind me of! Great job guys again.

title: Vernissage hos Gud
roles: Den Rike FabrikÃ¶ren Med HÃ¶g Hatt

title: To stage the music: Heiner Goebbels
Pulpit Gangster
roles: Allen Jr. Girlfriend In Red Sheet

review_text: I don't know who are what they were thinking?! Who greenlighted TRAIN WRECK of a BAD video and called it a movie?!! The script; actors; writing and directingbwere all just HORRIBLE!!!

Good movie, scenery could have been better but over all still good acting and cast. Love the director he makes really good movies. On a serious note it's based on a real life event and person that's the crazy part. The book is good too.
Amazon Prime started autoplaying it... The acting is good for the style of movie.
Adai Mazhai Kaalam is a must watch movie and sets off 2023 on a big bang for Malaysian Tamil movie industry!
I really enjoyed the film. The arduous journey home was a depiction of the struggles of the characters and also the resilience of the human spirit.

10/10 Past, present & future. These elements were played off in such a perfect manner in this movie and the setting alternated smoothly in a way that viewers will be able to understand. An alternate reality concept was also brilliantly used. The actors managed to well portray the emotions of the characters in the movie. Definitely relatable to most people's life. It started off with a love story vibe, moved on with a strong friendship vibe, continuing with another love story vibe but ... ended with a mother's love. I've never seen such a well thought out plot and yet I couldn't find any loopholes in it. All of these were blended into one single movie. A truly amazing Malaysian movie that was worth watching. The movie portrayed a lot of realistic situations & decisions which can make the audience react and relate to.

This movie explores the subject of how mortality affects us all and why every second matters. Wonderful story-tellin through captivating music and a natural cast. A must watch for those looking for life inspirations!

Where do I even begin? Adai Mazhai Kaalam took me on an extraordinary cinematic journey that left me utterly captivated and emotionally shaken. This film has a unique ability to reach deep within your soul and make you question the very essence of what it means to be human. From the opening scene to the closing credits, AMK had me on the edge of my seat, completely immersed in its powerful storytelling. It struck a chord within me that I haven't felt in a long time. The performances in AMK were nothing short of exceptional. The actors breathed life into their characters, making them relatable and genuine. The screenplay was a beautifully written, effortlessly taking us through moments of joy, heartbreak, and introspection. To the entire cast and crew of AMK, thank you for pouring your hearts and souls into this project. Your dedication and talent shine through every frame, creating an unforgettable cinematic experience that will stay with me forever. I wholeheartedly recommend Adai Mazhai Kaalam to everyone!!

A great movie. I have never watched a Malaysian Tamil movie that has a great impact to the audiences. It has delivered the message the crew try to give to the audiences. A great performance by each and everyone in this movie. The songs was very beautiful. The comedy sense was very nice. I have really enjoyed each and every moment in there. A second time in the theater would be a must for me and my girlfriend. Every Tamilans in Malaysia should support this movie in theater. Congratulations to the entire team. I love guys. Hope you guys can do more movies such as this. #Support local artist. #Support Tamilans.

Thanks for making this movie. It's meaningful movie which earn my tears. I usually don't comment for any movies I watched but this I am writing my pov with thousands feeling. This is a great movie which we have to watch and cheer it up and learn the lesson from this movie. Thanks for making this movie , really. It's amazing. Love , family and friends is united in this movie.....I never thought I'll cry for movie but this movie break my record....
It's why we have to always appreciate and be grateful to the loved one surrounding us because we can't estimate the time we go...I feel so touched when Suriyan still waiting for Chandra for express his love...

This is the best ever movie made in Malaysia. I cant stop my eyes tears in climax. How does this movie nominated but didnt win. Bias Malaysian awards giving ppl with existing fame and popularity. This movie, sound quality, music, each and every framing suitable with the scene and emotion. Screenplay top notch. Every actors, performed really fantastic. This movie shall won every single award in Malaysia. The director made a superb movie. Such detailings and references and the way the movie travels with our heart. Omg. Dear Malaysia producers, enough wasting money on others. Put it on this director. KARTHIK SHAMALAN. The man who is making Malaysian Tamil movies to the next level. Way Better than many Bollyoods and Kollywoods movie.

title: Suzan & Freek: Tussen jou en mij
roles: Self - Managing Director Sony Music Entertainment

review_text: As a viewer, I found "The Monster" to be an awful cinematic experience. The acoustics were woefully inadequate and the auditory elements of the film proved to be a constant distraction. Despite the premise of the story being intriguing, the execution of the film was lackluster. The pacing of the narrative was plodding and I found myself becoming disengaged with the plot. Furthermore, the monster was never adequately fleshed out or explored, leaving me feeling unsatisfied and underwhelmed. The film had the potential to be a thought-provoking exploration of a closed community during a pandemic, but instead it fell flat. I also thought at some point, that the movie was a 'troll', due to random and bad acting. The ending proved to be particularly anticlimactic, lacking any sort of resolution or satisfying conclusion, it was a culmination of all the shortcomings of the movie. I would not recommend this film to any discerning cinephile, as it fails to live up to its potential and ultimately proves to be a forgettable.

I have to be honest: Normally, I dislike biography type of artist movies, but man oh man what was this a great movie. I enjoyed the visuals, the background emotions and is makes you curious about where their journey will take them.

Right, well as I stumbled upon this 2023 comedy titled "Girls' Fright Out", from writer and director Steve Moon, by sheer random chance here in 2025, of course I opted to watch it, since it was a movie that I had neither heard about, nor actually ever seen. I looked up the movie here on IMDb, and saw that it had landed a whopping 1.0 rating, so I have to say that I didn't exactly harbor any expectations to the movie.

This series was very poorly written. It was also badly acted, and I am being nice! As a professional actor, it makes me want to vomit on a cracker seeing acting this bad. I mean seriously? Who wrote this stuff, a third grader? The special effects are also substandard. This is not creepy or scary at all. I get scared more seeing myself in the mirror every morning. There is no substance to the stories. The girl in the first clip...Who calls their dad like that? These stores are not even close to being believable whatsoever. I fully understand that this is my opinion, however, this is a major waste of time.

Let's meet Halfway provides a surprisingly sober and personal story with a story that is deep and keeps you watching. The direction is fantastic and the balance of the two directors is commendable. Boasting smart cinematography and a warm script, this film rides on the shoulders of its two leads who deliver stellar performances with human emotions and fully developed character. Though a little generic and possibly not earning the ending without more work, this film is a success and genuinely moving. Films like this so often slide under the radar which is a shame because the talent and art on display here is great.
A graveyard ghoul tells several creepy short stories.

Taking advantage of a holiday to go to the cinema and the only film playing at a decent time with an interesting plot was this one but it turned out to be one of the worst cinematic experiences of my life.

review_text: The stunning visuals of the Andaman Islands provide a breathtaking backdrop for the stories of the Karen people. A powerful and thought-provoking portrayal of the challenges faced by indigenous communities worldwide.

title: Xi Xing Ji: Anying Mo Cheng

review_text: Nuptse is a raw and visceral exploration of the human collective spirit. It follows the legendary "Gang des Moustaches" HÃ©lias Millerioux, FrÃ©dÃ©ric Degoulet, and Benjamin Guigonnet, as they attempt a direct line on the south face of Nuptse, a nearly 8,000-meter wall of rock and ice that has long been considered "the absolute inaccessible."
What if spooky technology? What then?

title: Greybeard: The Man, the Myth, the Mississippi

review_text: Expectations were very high and the film certainly exceeded all those expectations. Wonderful production, a great story line, very funny at times, entertaining throughout, encouraging for young and old.

Who amongst us has not dreamed of accomplishing a great feat? Dale Sanders not only dreams, but puts a goal in his sights, one foot in front of the other, one paddle stroke at a time, and makes it it happen. This film is extraordinary. Not only in capturing the essence of this man, but also in portraying the people and events that led up to and supported Dale's efforts to recapture his world record. Visually stunning, my eyes never wanted to blink to ensure I missed nothing. Big kudos to the team of folks that were able to convert 87 days to minutes and let all who view this film feel like they were part of the journey. I look forward to experiencing it again.

This film is entertaining to say the least. From the quirky energy that Dale has to the events that take place. It is a film that is an inspiration to all. The Young and especially the old. Stay active, stay healthy, and live a long life. The artistic aspects of the film is one that I can appreciate and I am excited for when this film will be available for purchase.

This documentary is superb and as River Angels who participated in Dale's expedition it is great to see it encapsulated. In the Headwaters Section, we provided the pontoon photography platform for Dale's crossing of Lakes Irving and Bemidji. We were fortunate to host Dale and his enterauge for lunch at our place on the banks of the Mississippi. We especially enjoyed the selection of music as well as glimpses into his life. It is unfortunate that Stan Stark passed away during this past year and will be unable to challenge Dale's record. We also had the pleasure of meeting Stan following his record trip, and hosting him at our place for lunch. Stan was also an extraordinary man. Ron&Judy URM 1284.

I saw this film at its world premiere at the Lookout Wild Film Festival in Chattanooga, TN and it stole the show.
